title: Factor pre-training in Bayesian multivariate logistic models

sections.text:
#### Abstract

This article focuses on inference in logistic regression for high-dimensional binary outcomes. A popular approach induces dependence across the outcomes by including latent factors in the linear predictor. Bayesian approaches are useful for characterizing uncertainty in inferring the regression coefficients, factors and loadings, while also incorporating hierarchical and shrinkage structure. However, Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms for posterior computation face challenges in scaling to high-dimensional outcomes. Motivated by applications in ecology, we exploit a blessing of dimensionality to motivate pre-estimation of the latent factors. Conditionally on the factors, the outcomes are modeled via independent logistic regressions. We implement Gaussian approximations in parallel in inferring the posterior on the regression coefficients and loadings, including a simple adjustment to obtain credible intervals with valid frequentist coverage. We show posterior concentration properties and excellent empirical performance in simulations. The methods are applied to insect biodiversity data in Madagascar.


Ecology; Factor analysis; High-dimensional; Joint species distribution model; Latent variable model; Multivariate logistic regression

## 1 INTRODUCTION

High-dimensional binary observations are frequently recorded in ecological studies where the presence or absence of a large number of species $p$ is documented at $n$ sampling sites (Abrego et al., 2018; Ovaskainen et al., 2020; Abrego et al., 2024; Ovaskainen et al., 2024). Data consist of a $n \times p$ matrix $Y=\left[y_{i j}\right]_{i j}$, where $y_{i j}=1$ if the $j$-th species was observed in the $i$-th sample or 0 otherwise. Ecologists are often interested in inferring relationships between sample-specific covariates $x_{i}=\left(x_{i 1}, \ldots, x_{i q}\right)^{\top}$, such as temperature and precipitation, and species occurrences, while also inferring across-species dependence in occurrence. Such inferences are based on joint species distribution models, corresponding to multivariate binary regression models for $y_{i}=\left(y_{i 1}, \ldots, y_{i p}\right)^{\top}$ given $x_{i}$ (Warton et al., 2015; Ovaskainen et al., 2017a,b; Tikhonov et al., 2020; Rahman et al., 2024; Stolf and Dunson, 2024).

A popular approach induces dependence in species occurrence through a type of generalized linear latent variable model (Moustaki and Knott, 2000), which lets

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(y_{i j}=1 \mid x_{i}, \eta_{i}\right)=h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\lambda_{j}^{\top} \eta_{i}\right), \quad \eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right), \quad(i=1, \ldots, n)
$$

where $h: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow(0,1)$ is a link function, $B=\left[\begin{array}{lll}\beta_{1} & \ldots & \beta_{p}\end{array}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times q}$ is a matrix of regression coefficients, $\eta_{i} \in \mathbb{R}^{k}$ are sample-specific latent factors, $\Lambda=\left[\begin{array}{lll}\lambda_{1} & \ldots & \lambda_{p}\end{array}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times k}$ are factor loadings and $p \gg k$. The factor term induces across-outcome dependence in a parsimonious manner.

Calculating the likelihood of $y_{i} \mid x_{i}$ with $\eta_{i}$ marginalized out typically involves an intractable integral, motivating a literature on likelihood approximations. Niku et al. (2017, 2019a) developed an efficient implementation of the Laplace approximation proposed by Huber et al. (2004), while Hui et al. (2017); Niku et al. (2019b); Korhonen et al. (2022) developed variational approximations. These methods take a few hours for each model fit for $p \approx 1,000$, leading to computational problems in our motivating applications, which have $p=10,000-100,000$. Kidziński et al. (2022) (GMF, henceforth) proposed a penalized quasi-likelihood estimator with better scalability, but their method takes up to several hours for each model fit, requires multiple fits for hyperparameter tuning, and does not provide uncertainty quantification without adding substantially to computation - for example, the authors suggest using bootstrap. The experiments in Section 4 and Section F of the Supplementary Materials provide more details on running times.

Bayesian inference can bypass calculating such integrals relying on data augmentation Gibbs samplers (Polson et al., 2013; Albert and Chib, 1993), alternating between sampling the loading matrix, $\Lambda$, the latent factors, $\eta_{i}$ 's, and other parameters including $B$ (Ovaskainen et al., 2017b). However, these algorithms suffer from poor mixing and slow convergence in high dimensions. Although pseudo-marginal algorithms can potentially be used relying on a Monte Carlo approximation to the marginal likelihood (Andrieu and Roberts, 2009; Doucet et al., 2015), such algorithms have not been sufficiently scalable in our experiments. Alternatively, one can rely on analytic approximations to the posterior (Blei et al., 2017; Kucukelbir et al., 2017; Ranganath et al., 2014; Hoffman et al., 2013; Buettner et al., 2017; Wang and Stephens, 2021; Ghahramani and Beal, 1999). For instance, variational inference approximates the posterior with a more tractable distribution, but typically with little theoretical guarantees and severe under estimation of uncertainty.

An issue rendering frequentist and Bayesian methods impractical in high dimensions is the need to integrate out the latent factors. An alternative is to estimate latent factors, loadings, and coefficients jointly. Joint maximum likelihood estimates (Birnbaum, 1968) treat latent factors as fixed unknown parameters and can be computationally efficient using alternating optimization. Such approaches produce inconsistent estimates in the classic asymptotic regime where $n$ diverges and $p$ remains fixed (Haberman, 1977). However, many applications are characterized by high-dimensional data with $p \gg n$ making the big $n$ fixed $p$ argument less relevant. Chen et al. $(2019,2020)$ show consistency of joint maximum likelihood estimates as both $n$ and $p$ diverge, but without considering general covariate matrices or providing uncertainty quantification. Alternatively, Chattopadhyay

et al. (2024); Mauri et al. (2025) propose fast approaches for Bayesian inference in linear single- and multi-study factor models for Gaussian data in which latent factors are estimated by singular value decomposition and loadings and residual variances are given a conjugate prior given the factors. They proved that the induced posterior on the covariance concentrates at the true values and has entry-wise credible intervals with correct coverage.

Motivated by the above literature, we propose Fast multivariate Logistic Analysis for Inference in Regression (FLAIR). We first compute joint maximum a posteriori estimates for latent factors, factor loadings, and regression coefficients. The posterior for the loadings and regression coefficients given the factors has a simple product form across the outcomes, and we approximate each term in this product via a Gaussian distribution. By including a careful variance inflation, we obtain credible intervals with valid frequentist for the regression coefficients and induced covariance of the linear predictor. Fixing latent variables at a point estimate in approximating the posterior of $\Lambda$ and $B$ can be justified because as $p$ grows, an increasing number of variables load on the latent factors and their marginal posterior concentrates. The product form allows FLAIR to be parallelized, making the implementation highly efficient on multicore machines. Hyperparameters are selected in a data-driven and automated manner.

An anonymous referee pointed out the parallel development by Lee et al. (2024) (LVHML, henceforth). LVHML consider a longitudinal version of model (S13) where the intercept term can vary over time. Hence, for the $j$-th element in the $i$-th sample and the $t$-th time, LVHML lets

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(y_{i j t}=1 \mid x_{i}\right)=h\left(\alpha_{j t}+x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{j}\right), \quad(i=1, \ldots, n ; j=1, \ldots, p ; t=1, \ldots, T)
$$

where $T$ is the total number of time points. LVHML assumes latent factors $\left(\left\{\eta_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{n}\right)$ are fixed unknown constants and imposes orthogonality between latent factors and covariates for identifiability. Fixed factors prevent the interpretation of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ as latent covariance between outcomes. Lee et al. (2024) provide central limit theorems (Theorems 3 and 6 in Lee et al. (2024)) to quantify uncertainty about point estimates. However, in our experiments, the confidence intervals obtained using these results suffered from non-negligible undercoverage, which seems to be persistent at different values of $n$ and $p$. We refer to Section F. 2 in the Supplementary Material for additional details on the performance of FLAIR and LVHML in longitudinal scenarios.

Our contributions include: (i) an alternating optimization scheme to compute a point estimate, which is substantially faster than current alternatives for very large $p$ scenarios, with comparable or better accuracy, while requiring minimal or no hyperparameter tuning, (ii) theoretical support for our methodology showing consistency of joint maximum a posteriori and posterior point estimates as $n$ and $p$ diverge and posterior contraction around the truth, and (iii) a method to accurately quantify uncertainty without computationally expensive Markov chain Monte Carlo. Although we are motivated by ecology applications, our method is useful in a wide range of settings, from genetics (Stegle et al., 2012) to psychology (Skrondal and Rabe-Hesketh, 2004).

# 2 Methodology
### 2.1 Notation

We start by establishing the notation used in the paper. For a matrix $A$, we denote by $\|A\|_{2},\|A\|_{F},\|A\|_{*}$, $\|A\|_{\infty}$ its spectral, Frobenius, nuclear and entry-wise infinity norm, respectively, and by $s_{l}(A)$ its $l$-th largest singular value. For a vector $v$, we denote by $\|v\|,\|v\|_{\infty}$ its Euclidean and entry-wise infinity norm, respectively. Moreover, for two sequences $\left(a_{n}\right)_{n \leq 1},\left(b_{n}\right)_{n \leq 1}$, we say $a_{n} \leq b_{n}$ if there exist two constants $N_{0}<\infty$ and $C<\infty$, such that $a_{n} \leq C b_{n}$ for every $n>N_{0}$. We say $a_{n} \times b_{n}$ if and only if $a_{n} \leq b_{n}$ and $b_{n} \leq a_{n}$.

### 2.2 General Approach

We consider data generated from model (S13) with $h^{-1}(\pi)=\log \{\pi /(1-\pi)\}$ the logit link function. Letting $z_{i j}=x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{j}$ denote the linear predictor, and marginalizing out $\eta_{i}$, we get

$$
y_{i j} \mid z_{i j} \sim \operatorname{Ber}\left\{h\left(z_{i j}\right)\right\}, \quad z_{i} \sim N_{p}\left(B x_{i}, \Lambda \Lambda^{\top}\right), \quad(j=1, \ldots, p ; i=1, \ldots, n)
$$

where $z_{i}=\left(z_{i 1}, \ldots, z_{i p}\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$. The linear predictor for sample $i, z_{i}$, follows a $p$ dimensional singular Gaussian distribution with a rank $k$ covariance, $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$, which models across column dependence. Thus, marginal and cooccurrence probabilities depend uniquely on $B$ and $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$, with $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ characterizing across outcome dependence not captured by covariate effects. If the latent factors $M=\left[\begin{array}{lll}\eta_{1} & \ldots & \eta_{n}\end{array}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}$ were known, inference on the rows of $\Lambda$ and $B\left(\left\{\lambda_{j}, \beta_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{p}\right)$ could be carried out by $p$ independent logistic regressions using the augmented covariate matrix $[X M]$, since elements of $y_{i}$ are independent conditionally on the latent factor $\eta_{i}$.

Motivated by this consideration, we develop a computationally efficient approach to approximate the posterior of $B, \Lambda$. We first obtain a joint maximum a posteriori estimate for the latent factors, loadings, and regression coefficients using a combination of matrix factorization and optimization techniques. Then, given the estimated latent factors $\hat{M}$, we characterize the uncertainty of $\Lambda$ and $B$ by their conditional posterior distribution. This conditional posterior is equivalent to the product of posteriors for $\left\{\lambda_{j}, \beta_{j}\right\}$ over $j=1, \ldots, p$. Each of these component posteriors can be calculated in parallel and accurately approximated with Gaussian distributions.

For high-dimensional data with large $p$ and $p \gg k$, many variables tend to load on each factor, leading to posterior concentration for each $\eta_{i}$. This blessing of dimensionality reduces concern about under-estimation of uncertainty due to fixing latent factors at a point estimate. We introduce an analytic inflation factor to the variance of the posterior, which can be calculated without tuning, ensuring valid frequentist coverage on average across credible intervals in all the experiments we considered, with coverage very close to the nominal level in each individual experiment. The complete procedure is reported in Algorithm 1.

# 2.3 Joint Maximum a Posteriori Estimate 

We assume truncated normal priors on the $\lambda_{j}$ 's and $\beta_{j}$ 's,

$$
\lambda_{j} \mid \tau_{\lambda_{j}} \sim T N_{k}\left(0, \tau_{\lambda_{j}}^{2} I_{k},\left[-c_{\Lambda}, c_{\Lambda}\right]^{k}\right), \quad \beta_{j} \mid \tau_{\beta_{j}} \sim T N_{q}\left(0, \tau_{\beta_{j}}^{2} I_{q},\left[-c_{B}, c_{B}\right]^{q}\right)
$$

for $j=1, \ldots, p$, where $T N_{m}(\mu, \Sigma, C)$ denotes a $m$-dimensional truncated normal distribution with mean $\mu$ and covariance $\Sigma$ supported on the set $C$. In addition, we use a truncated normal distribution for the latent factors,

$$
\eta_{i} \sim T N_{k}\left(0, I_{k},[-2 \sqrt{\log (k n)}, 2 \sqrt{\log (k n)}]^{k}\right), \quad(i=1, \ldots, n)
$$

$c_{\Lambda}$ and $c_{B}$ are user specified parameters that control the infinity norm of loadings and regression coefficients, respectively. Constraining the infinity norms of the model parameters and latent factors is useful for obtaining theoretical support for our methodology. In our experiments, $c_{\Lambda}$ and $c_{B}$ are set by default to 10 to obtain a weak constraint. Computing the constrained joint maximum a posteriori estimate for $(M, \Lambda, B)$ under the priors specified in (3)-(4) is equivalent to solving the following constrained optimization problem,

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})= & \arg \max _{M, \Lambda, B} \log p(M, \Lambda, B \mid Y, X) \\
& \text { s.t. }\|M\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \log ^{1 / 2}(k n),\|\Lambda\|_{\infty} \leq c_{\Lambda},\|B\|_{\infty} \leq c_{B}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log p(M, \Lambda, B \mid Y, X)= & C+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p} \log p\left(y_{i j} \mid x_{i}, \lambda_{j}, \beta_{j}, \eta_{i}\right) \\
& -\frac{1}{2}\|M\|_{2}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{tr}\left(\Lambda^{+} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \Lambda\right)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{tr}\left(B^{+} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} B\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\Sigma_{\Lambda}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\tau_{\lambda_{1}}^{2}, \ldots, \tau_{\lambda_{p}}^{2}\right), \Sigma_{B}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\tau_{\beta_{1}}^{2}, \ldots, \tau_{\beta_{p}}^{2}\right)$, and $C$ is a constant. We solve (5) by iterating between the following steps until convergence.

1. Given the estimate for the latent factors $\hat{M}$, we update $B$ and $\Lambda$ via

$$
(\hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})=\arg \max _{\Lambda, B} \log p(\hat{M}, \Lambda, B \mid Y, X) \quad \text { s.t. }\|\Lambda\|_{\infty} \leq c_{\Lambda},\|B\|_{\infty} \leq c_{B}
$$

2. Given the estimate for the loadings and regression matrices $(\hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$, we update $M$ via

$$
\hat{M}=\arg \max _{M} \log p(M, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y, X) \quad \text { s.t. }\|M\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \log ^{1 / 2}(k n)
$$

Each step in the optimization algorithm is parallelizable across columns or rows of $Y$, is solved via a projected Newton-Raphson method, and has a cost of $O\left\{n p(k+q)^{3} \max _{\text {_ }}$ iter $\right\}$, where max_iter is an upper bound on the number of Newton steps of each routine. We stop iterations once the relative increase in the log-posterior

is smaller than a small threshold $\epsilon$; in our experiments, we set $\epsilon=0.001$. The starting point for the algorithm is found via an initialization based on singular value decomposition adapted from Chen et al. (2019). This initialization was shown to provide consistent estimates for the loadings in Zhang et al. (2020), when $X=1_{n}$. More details are provided in the Supplementary Material. The solution to (5), $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$, is post-processed and transformed into the triplet $(\tilde{M}, \tilde{\Lambda}, \tilde{B})$, so that $X \tilde{B}^{\top}+\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}=X \tilde{B}^{\top}+\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}, \tilde{M}^{\top} \tilde{M}=n I_{k}$, and $\tilde{M}^{\top} X=0$. This procedure is detailed in the Supplementary Material and leaves the value of the linear predictor unchanged, while enforcing the matrix product of the transpose of the latent factors with itself and with the matrix of covariates to be equal to their expectation. We take $\tilde{M}$ as our final estimate for $M$. We show that $\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}$ and $\tilde{B}$ are consistent in terms of the relative Frobenius error in Theorem 1. In the next section, we propose an approach for uncertainty quantification.

# 2.4 Posterior Computation 

In a Bayesian setting, uncertainty in $\Lambda$ and $B$ is encoded in their posterior distribution

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(\Lambda, B \mid Y, X) & \propto \int p(Y \mid X, \Lambda, B, M) p(B) p(\Lambda) p(M) d M \\
& \propto \int p(\Lambda, B \mid Y, X, M) p(M \mid Y, X) d M
\end{aligned}
$$

As described in the introduction, approximating (9) via Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling is often impractical and existing alternatives are not satisfactory. We are motivated by the consideration that, when $p$ is large, estimates of latent factors become more accurate and their marginal posterior distribution, $p(M \mid Y, X)$, concentrates. Hence, we ignore uncertainty in $M$ and approximate the posterior distribution of $(\Lambda, B)$ via their conditional posterior distribution given the estimate for $M, \tilde{M}$,

$$
p(\Lambda, B \mid Y, X) \approx p(\Lambda, B \mid Y, X, \tilde{M})
$$

Conditionally on the latent factors, columns of $Y$ are independent. Thus, for independent priors on rows of $\Lambda$ and $B$, the right hand side of (10) factorizes into the product of $p$ terms,

$$
p(\Lambda, B \mid Y, X, \tilde{M})=\prod_{j=1}^{p} p\left(\lambda_{j}, \beta_{j} \mid Y^{(j)}, X, \tilde{M}\right)
$$

where $Y^{(j)}$ is the $j$-th column of $Y$, and

$$
p\left(\lambda_{j}, \beta_{j} \mid Y^{(j)}, X, \tilde{M}\right) \propto p\left(\lambda_{j} \mid \tau_{\lambda_{j}}\right) p\left(\beta_{j} \mid \tau_{\beta_{j}}\right) \prod_{i=1}^{n} h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\tilde{\eta}_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{j}\right)^{y_{i j}}\left\{1-h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\tilde{\eta}_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{j}\right)\right\}^{1-y_{i j}}
$$

To speed-up posterior computation, we replace conditional posterior distributions of $\theta_{j}=\left(\lambda_{j}, \beta_{j}\right)$ 's given $M=\tilde{M}$, terms on the right hand side in (11), with Gaussian approximations,

$$
\tilde{\Pi}_{j}\left(\theta_{j}\right)=N_{k+q}\left(\theta_{j} \mid \tilde{\theta}_{j}, \rho^{2} \tilde{V}_{j}\right), \quad(j=1, \ldots, p)
$$

where $\tilde{\theta}_{j}=\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{j}^{\top}, \tilde{\beta}_{j}^{\top}\right)^{\top}$ is the estimate described in the previous section,

$$
\tilde{V}_{j}=\left[-\left.\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \theta_{j} \partial \theta_{j}^{\top}} \log p\left(Y^{(j)} \mid X, \tilde{M}, \lambda_{j}, \beta_{j}\right)+\log p\left(\lambda_{j} \mid \hat{\tau}_{\lambda_{j}}\right)+\log p\left(\beta_{j} \mid \hat{\tau}_{\beta_{j}}\right)\right|_{\theta_{j}=\tilde{\theta}_{j}}\right]^{-1}
$$

is the corresponding inverse negative Hessian and $\rho>1$ is a variance inflation factor that is fixed in advance to achieve correct frequentist coverage of posterior credible intervals. Section E. 2 of the Supplementary Materials presents a closed-form formula for $\rho$. In our experiments, the credible intervals obtained from $\tilde{\Pi}$ for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $B$ had accurate frequentist coverage.

We approximate the posterior for $(\Lambda, B)$ in (9) by approximating (11) via

$$
\tilde{\Pi}\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{p}\right)=\prod_{j=1}^{p} \tilde{\Pi}_{j}\left(\theta_{j}\right)
$$

Hyperparameters $\tau_{B}=\left(\tau_{\beta_{1}}, \ldots, \tau_{\beta_{p}}\right)$ and $\tau_{\Lambda}=\left(\tau_{\lambda_{1}}, \ldots, \tau_{\lambda_{p}}\right)$ are selected using a data-driven strategy reported in the Supplementary Material.

# 2.5 Choice of the Number of Latent Factors 

To select the number of factors, we opt for the joint likelihood-based information criterion introduced in Chen and $\mathrm{Li}(2021)$ that takes the form

$$
\operatorname{JIC}(k)=-2 l_{k}+k \max (n, p) \log \{\min (n, p)\}
$$

where $l_{k}$ is the value of the joint log-likelihood computed at the joint maximum likelihood estimate when the latent dimension is equal to $k$. To avoid computing the joint maximum likelihood estimate for every value of $k$, we approximate $l_{k}$ with $l_{k} \approx \hat{l}_{k}=\log p\left(Y \mid X, \hat{M}_{k}, \hat{\Lambda}_{k}, \hat{B}_{k}\right)$, where $\left(\hat{M}_{k}, \hat{\Lambda}_{k}, \hat{B}_{k}\right)$ are obtained via the matrix-factorization technique described in Section D. 1 of the supplemental. Thus, we set

$$
\hat{k}=\arg \min _{k=1, \ldots, k_{\max }} \operatorname{JIC}(k), \quad \operatorname{JIC}(k)=-2 \hat{l}_{k}+k \max (n, p) \log \{\min (n, p)\}
$$

where $k_{\max }$ is an upperbound to the latent dimension. The criterion in (14) always picked the correct number of latent factors in the simulations reported in Section 4.

Algorithm 1 FLAIR procedure to obtain $N_{M C}$ approximate posterior samples.
Require: The data matrix $Y \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$, the design matrix $X$, the number of Monte Carlo samples $N_{M C}$, the upper bound on the number of factors $k_{\max }$, and the upper bound on the magnitude of the regression coefficients and factor loadings $c_{B}, c_{\Lambda}$.

Step 1: Estimate the number of latent factors via equation (14).
Step 2: Obtain initial estimates $\hat{B}, \hat{\Lambda}$ as described in Section D. 1 in the supplemental and let $\hat{\tau}_{\lambda_{j}}=$ $\mathcal{T}\left(k^{-1 / 2}\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right\|\right)$ and $\hat{\tau}_{\hat{\theta}_{j}}=\mathcal{T}\left(k^{-1 / 2}\left\|\hat{\beta}_{j}\right\|\right)$, where $\mathcal{T}$ is defined as $\mathcal{T}(x)=x 1_{\{x \in(l, u)\}}+l 1_{\{x \leq l\}}+u 1_{\{x \geq u\}}$ and $l=0.5, u=20$.
Step 3: Compute $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ by solving (5).
Step 4: Post-process $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ to obtain $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ as described in Section D. 3 of the Supplementary Material.
Step 5: Estimate the coverage-correction factor $\rho$ as described in Section E. 2 of the Supplementary Material.
Step 6:
for $j=1$ to $p$ in parallel do
for $s=1$ to $N_{M C}$ do
Sample independently $\theta_{j}^{(s)}=\left(\beta_{j}^{(s)}, \lambda_{j}^{(s)}\right)$ from $\theta_{j}^{(s)} \sim N_{k \leftrightarrow q}\left(\hat{\theta}_{j}, \rho^{2} \hat{V}_{j}\right), \hat{\theta}_{j}=\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}^{\top}, \hat{\beta}_{j}^{\top}\right)^{\top}, \hat{V}_{j}$ is defined in (12).
Form $B^{(s)}=\left\{\beta_{1}^{(s)}, \cdots, \beta_{p}^{(s)}\right\}^{\top}$ and $\Lambda^{(s)}=\left\{\lambda_{1}^{(s)}, \cdots, \lambda_{p}^{(s)}\right\}^{\top}$.
Compute the corresponding sample for the latent covariance matrix as $\Lambda^{(s)} \Lambda^{(s) \top}$.
Output: $N_{M C}$ samples of the covariance matrix $\Lambda^{(1)} \Lambda^{(1) \top}, \ldots, \Lambda^{\left(N_{M C}\right)} \Lambda^{\left(N_{M C}\right) \top}$ and of the regression coefficients matrix $B^{(1)}, \ldots, B^{\left(N_{M C}\right)}$.

# 3 Theoretical Support 

Before stating the theoretical results, we enumerate some regularity conditions.
Assumption 1. The data are generated according (S13) with
true parameters $B=B_{0}=\left(\beta_{01} \cdots \beta_{0 p}\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times q}$ and $\Lambda=\Lambda_{0}=\left(\lambda_{01} \cdots \lambda_{0 p}\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times k}$. We denote by $M_{0}$ the matrix whose rows are given by the true latent factors $\eta_{0 i}$ 's and define $Z_{0}=M_{0} \Lambda^{\top}+X B_{0}^{\top}$.

Assumption 2. Data dimensionality $p=p_{n}$ satisfies $p_{n} \rightarrow \infty, \log \left(p_{n}\right) / n=o(1), p_{n} \gtrsim n^{1 / 2}$.
Assumption 2 ensures that the number of outcomes $p$ grows asymptotically with $n$ at most at a polynomial rate and not slower than its square root.

Assumption 3. The true loadings $\Lambda_{0}$ satisfy $s_{k}\left(\Lambda_{0}\right) \propto p_{n}^{1 / 2}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ and $\left\|\Lambda_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq c_{\Lambda}<\infty$.
Assumption 4. The true regression coefficients matrix $B_{0}$ satisfies $\left\|B_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq c_{B}$.
Assumption 5. The design matrix $X$ satisfies $\|X\|_{\infty} \leq c_{x} \log ^{1 / 2}(q n)$ with probability at least $1-C^{\prime} / n$ and $s_{q}\left(X^{\top} X\right) \asymp n$, where $C^{\prime}$ is a positive constant not depending on $n$ and $p_{n}$.

Assumption 5 holds if, for instance, the $x_{i}$ 's are independent samples from a sub-Gaussian distribution. Assumptions $3-5$ ensure $\left\|Z_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}$, with high probability, since, as we show in the supplement $\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \log ^{1 / 2}(k n)$, with probability at least $1-2 / n$.

Assumption 6. The hyperparameters $\tau_{B}, \tau_{\Lambda}, k, \rho$ are fixed constants.
First, we show that the accuracy of point estimates improves as $n, p$ diverge. Treating the distribution arising from (13) as our posterior distribution, the posterior mean of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $B$ are available in closed form once the $\tilde{\lambda}_{j}$ 's, $\tilde{V}_{j}$ 's, and $\tilde{\beta}_{j}$ 's have been computed and are given by

$$
\tilde{\Sigma}=E_{\tilde{\Pi}}\left(\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}\right)=\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}+\rho^{2} \tilde{D}, \quad E_{\tilde{\Pi}}(B)=\tilde{B}
$$

where $E_{\tilde{\Pi}}$ denotes the expectation under $\tilde{\Pi}, \tilde{D}=\operatorname{diag}\left\{\operatorname{tr}\left(\tilde{V}_{\lambda_{1}}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{tr}\left(\tilde{V}_{\lambda_{p}}\right)\right\}, \tilde{V}_{\lambda_{j}}$ is the marginal posterior variance of $\lambda_{j}$ from $\tilde{V}_{j}$, and $\tilde{\Lambda}$ and $\tilde{B}$ are matrices whose $j$-th rows are $\tilde{\lambda}_{j}$ and $\tilde{\beta}_{j}$ respectively. We show that $\tilde{\Sigma}$ and $\tilde{B}$ are consistent estimates; $\tilde{\Sigma}$ has a low-rank plus diagonal form. An alternative low-rank estimator can be obtained by discarding the diagonal part and estimating $\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ via $\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}$; this estimator has comparable asymptotic performance as shown below.

Theorem 1 (Accuracy of Point Estimates). Suppose Assumptions 1 -6 hold and define $\hat{Z}=X \hat{B}^{\top}+\hat{M} \hat{\Lambda}^{\top}$, where $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \tilde{B})$ is the solution to (5). Then, with probability at least $1-C / n$,

$$
\frac{1}{(n p)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}\left\{\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\}
$$

Moreover, define $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \tilde{B})$ as the triplet obtained post-processing the joint maximum a posteriori estimate $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \tilde{B})$ solution to (5). Then, with probability at least $1-C / n$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \min _{R \in \mathbb{R}^{K \times K} ; R^{\top} R \times I_{K}} \frac{1}{n}\left\|\hat{M} R-M_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}\left\{\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\}, \\
& \frac{\left\|\hat{\Sigma}-\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}}{\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}} \leq e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}\left\{\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\}, \\
& \frac{\left\|\hat{\Lambda} \hat{\Lambda}^{\top}-\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}}{\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}} \leq e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}\left\{\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\}, \\
& \frac{1}{\left(p_{n} q\right)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\tilde{B}-B_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}\left\{\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C$ and $c_{Z}$ are universal constants not depending on $n$ and $p_{n}$.
Proof. The proofs of all theoretical results are reported in the Supplementary Material.
Remark 1 (Blessing of Dimensionality). The magnitude of the errors of the joint maximum a posteriori estimates decrease at a rate $O\left(\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{1}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right)$ up to subpolynomal factors. Hence, we have a blessing of dimensionality with consistency holding only if both $n$ and $p_{n}$ diverge.

Remark 2 (Convergence Rate). The bound in Theorem 1 is less tight than the related bounds in Chen et al. (2019); Lee et al. (2024). This is due to different assumptions on latent factors and covariates. These works

assume that $\eta_{i}{ }^{\prime} \mathrm{s}$ and $x_{i}{ }^{\prime} \mathrm{s}$ lie in a compact space that is not dependent on $n$ and $p$, while our assumptions are more general, leading to the factor $e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}$ on the right-hand side of Theorem 1 We refer to the note after the proof of Theorem 1 in the Supplementary Material for a more detailed explanation.

The right-hand side of (16) is better than the rate in Chen et al. (2019) for the joint maximum likelihood estimate and the same up to subpolynomial terms as Chen et al. (2020), which focuses on confirmatory factor analysis with $X=1_{n}$. The result in (17) bounds the Procrustes error of the estimate for the latent factors $\tilde{M}$. In (18)-(19) and (20), we normalize the left-hand side by dividing by the norm of $\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ and $\left(p_{n} q\right)^{1 / 2}$ to make the estimation error comparable as the dimension $p_{n}$ increases.

Next, we characterize the contraction of the posterior distribution $\tilde{\Pi}$ around the true parameters.
Theorem 2 (Posterior Contraction). Suppose Assumptions 1 - 6 hold. Then, for $M \in \mathbb{R}$ sufficiently large, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p r\left[\tilde{\Pi}\left\{\frac{\left\|\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}-\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}}{\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}}>M \epsilon_{n}\right\} \leq C / n\right\} \geq 1-C / n \\
& p r\left[\tilde{\Pi}\left\{\frac{1}{\sqrt{p_{n} q}}\left\|B-B_{0}\right\|_{F}>M \epsilon_{n}\right\} \leq C / n\right] \geq 1-C / n
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\epsilon_{n}=e^{c_{Z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}\left\{\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}\left(p_{n}\right)}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\}$, pr and $\tilde{\Pi}$ denote the true data generating probability measure and the posterior probability measure induced by (13) respectively, and $C$ and $c_{Z}$ are universal constants not depending on $n$ and $p_{n}$.

For both $\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ and $B_{0}$, we rescale the distance by suitable quantities to take into account the growing dimension of the parameter space. The contraction rate is given by $\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{1}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}$ up to subpolynomal factors and is the same, modulo a logarithmic term, as rates for the estimates.

# 4 NUMERICAL EXPERIMENTS 

We conduct a simulation study to illustrate the performance of FLAIR in estimation accuracy and uncertainty quantification for $\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ and $B_{0}$, as well as computing time. We simulate data from model (S13), where parameters are generated as follows

$$
\lambda_{0 j l} \sim 0.5 \delta_{0}+0.5 T N\left(0, \sigma^{2},[-5,5]), \quad \beta_{0 j l^{\prime}} \sim 0.5 \delta_{0}+0.5 T N\left(0, \sigma^{2},[-5,5]\right)\right.
$$

for $j=1, \ldots, p, l=1, \ldots, k, l^{\prime}=1, \ldots, q$. We let the sample and outcome sizes be $(n, p) \in\{500,1000\} \times$ $\{1000,5000,10000\}$, and set $\sigma^{2}=0.5, k=q=100$.

![table_0](table_0)

Table 1: Comparison of the methods in terms of estimation accuracy. Root normalized squared error for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $B$, and running time. Estimation errors have been multiplied by $10^{2}$. We report mean and standard error over 50 replications. GMF - Newton and GMF - Airwls denote Kidziński et al. (2022)'s method fitted via the quasi Newton method and via alternating iteratively reweighted least square algorithm respectively.

For each configuration, we replicate the experiments 50 times. In each replicate, covariates and latent factors are generated as

$$
x_{i}=\left(1, x_{i 2}, \ldots x_{i q}\right), \quad x_{i j} \sim N(0,1), \quad \eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right) \quad(j=2, \ldots, q ; i=1, \ldots, n)
$$

We evaluate estimation accuracy for $\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ and $B_{0}$ via the Frobenius norm of the difference of the estimate and true parameter scaled by $\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}$ and $(p q)^{1 / 2}$ respectively, as in Section 3. We evaluated uncertainty quantification through the average frequentist coverage of equal-tail $95 \%$ credible intervals for individual parameters. For FLAIR, we use posterior means as point estimates, but other possible estimates mentioned above had similar performance.

We compare to GMF using code at https://github.com/kidzik/gmf, using either a Newton method with a simplified Hessian or alternating iteratively reweighted least squares. These two approaches had substantially different computing time and estimation accuracy, so we report results for both. For each replicate, we performed a random $80 \% / 20 \%$ train-test split and chose the hyperparameters to maximize the test set area under the ROC curve; then we re-fitted the model with the full data. In the supplemental, we consider scenarios with lowerdimensional parameters, longitudinal data, and without covariates, where we also include a comparison with standard implementations of generalized linear latent variable models (Hui et al., 2017; Korhonen et al., 2022), LVIML, and Chen et al. (2019)'s method, respectively.

Average frequentist coverage for entries of a random $100 \times 100$ submatrix of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $B$ for equi-tailed $95 \%$ credible intervals of FLAIR with and without applying the correction factor $\rho$ to the posterior variance. We report mean and standard error over 50 replications. All values have been multiplied by $10^{2}$.

Table 1 reports a comparison in terms of estimation accuracy and computational time. FLAIR is remarkably faster than GMF, even with the results in the table focusing only on model fitting time after hyperparameter tuning. In terms of estimation accuracy, FLAIR has a better performance in estimating $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ while being comparable in estimating $B$. GMF fitted via iterated least squares had extremely poor accuracy in some replicates affecting the overall performance when $(n, p) \in\{1000\} \times\{1000,5000\}$. Table 2 reports the coverage of credible intervals on average across the entries of $B$ and $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$. These results provide strong support for FLAIR in terms of providing well-calibrated credible intervals.

# 5 Application to Madagascar Arthropod Data 

We analyze data from Ovaskainen et al. (2024) measuring arthropod co-occurence. Arthropods are a vital component of any ecosystem, and characterizing their co-occurrence is of paramount importance in studying factors related to community assembly and biodiversity. Data were collected from 284 samples at 53 sampling sites in Madagascar. At each sampling site, arthropods were collected in Malaise traps and categorized according to their DNA through COI metabarcoding (Elbrecht et al., 2019) and the OptimOTU pipeline (Song et al., 2008). This produced 254312 operational taxonomic units, which we refer to as "species". Most are ultra-rare, with 211187 of these species present in $\leq 2$ samples. As covariates, we included log-transformed sequencing depth, mean precipitation and temperature, their interaction and squares, and four trigonometric terms to adjust for seasonal effects $\left(\cos \left(2 l \pi d_{i} / 365\right), \sin \left(2 l \pi d_{i} / 365\right)\right.$ with $l=1,2$, where $d_{i}$ denotes the day of sampling for the $i$-th observation). We standardized continuous covariates to have zero mean and unit standard deviation.

To allow comparisons with less computationally efficient alternatives, we initially focused our analysis on the 5656 species that were observed at least 15 times. Using the approach of Section 2.5, the estimated number of latent factors was $\hat{k}=7$. We applied a random stratified $80 \%-20 \%$ split to the data set, with stratification ensuring that the holdout set contains roughly the same proportions of 0 and 1 s as the training set. To choose the hyperparameters of GMF, we divided the holdout set into half into test and validation sets. All details are in the Supplement.

Obtaining FLAIR estimates took $\sim 15$ minutes while the average running time of GMF for each hyperparameter configuration was approximately 1 hour with the quasi-Newton algorithm and more than 5 hours with the iterated least squares algorithm. FLAIR obtained an area under the curve on the validation set of $96.53 \%$, while GMF with the best hyperparameter configuration yielded $95.30 \%$ and $78.28 \%$ for the Newton method and iterated least squares algorithm respectively. Hence, FLAIR achieved better predictive performance with considerable less computing time.

We reanalyzed the data including the 43125 species that were observed at least 3 times. For GMF, we did not optimize the hyperparameters again and fitted the model using the configurations chosen in the common species analysis described above and focused on the faster and more accurate quasi-Newton algorithm. FLAIR had considerably better out-of-sample predictive performance, having an area under the curve of $94.18 \%$ compared to the $87.86 \%$ for GMF. As expected, performance dropped off somewhat compared to the above common species analysis, since rare species are more difficult to predict.

In conducting inferences on the cross-species dependence in occurrence and covariate effects, we focused on an analysis of the complete data on the 5656 common species. Figure 1 illustrates species responses to measured covariates. The results imply that most arthropod species are sensitive to climate, including both temperature and precipitation, and seasonality. In addition, the impact of temperature and precipitation tends to be nonlinear. However, there is substantial heterogeneity among species in the signs of the coefficients, suggesting that ideal climate conditions are species-specific. There is no clear taxonomic clustering in the signs, suggesting that even closely related species may have different ideal climate conditions.

We are also interested in cross-species dependence in co-occurrence, which is captured by the $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ matrix. If the $j, j^{\prime}$ entry of this matrix is positive, then that pair of species may prefer similar habitat conditions or may have beneficial interactions. If the entry is negative, the two species may have adversarial interactions in competing for the same resources or having a predator-prey relationship, or may favor different conditions. Figure 2 shows the posterior mean of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ for 1000 randomly selected species; entries for which the $95 \%$ credible interval included 0 were set to 0 . If we order species according to the taxonomical tree (left panel), no particular structure is notable. If instead we reorder species using a dendrogram where pairwise similarities are measured by the posterior mean of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ (right panel), interesting patterns arise. For instance, there are blocks with positive pairwise dependence along the diagonal with mostly negative dependence off the blocks.

This suggests the presence of groups of species that are not taxonomically closely related and have positive and negative interactions and/or relationships with latent environmental conditions.

Figure 3 zooms in on 50 species for which species' names are available. In the upper right corner we observe a group of species with positive pairwise dependence supporting again the existance of positive interactions of species which are not taxonomically close. For instance, this group includes various beetles belonging to the Coleoptera order (the Rhagium inquisitor, Dalopius marginatusn and Thanasimus formicarius) as well as species from different orders, such as Entomobrya nivalis, a species of slender springtails, and the Ceromya silacea, a species of fly.

# 6 DiscuSsion 

We presented a method for fast estimation with accurate uncertainty quantification for multivariate logistic regression models with high-dimensional outcomes. There are several important directions for future research. An interesting avenue is to extend factor pre-estimation to any generalized linear latent variable model and to latent space models for network data (Hoff et al., 2002; Durante and Dunson, 2014), while formalizing the theory on accuracy relative to the true posterior and frequentist coverage of the corresponding posterior approximations. In particular, it is worthwhile to develop a similar coverage correction strategy to bypass the

need for expensive Gibbs sampling routines to quantify uncertainty, while allowing fast and accurate Bayesian inference in many important applied settings.

It is also interesting to increase flexibility by developing extensions to (1) non-linear latent factor models and (2) more complex and structured priors. For (1), an estimate of latent factors might be obtained via a suitable adaptation of a non-linear dimensionality reduction technique (Lawrence, 2003; Coifman et al., 2005) and inference on the non-linear map could proceed adopting some non-parametric prior. Regarding (2), it is desirable to consider a hierarchical prior formulation, for instance incorporating phylogenetic information of species, shrinking regression coefficients and factor loadings of similar species towards a common estimate. This seems particularly important in our motivating ecological application, where we expect estimates for rare species to benefit from borrowing of information.

Finally, applying FLAIR to other high-dimensional data sets measuring biodiversity to assess the impact of climate and environmental disruption on species communities while uncovering interesting interactions between species is an important direction. Indeed, we expect FLAIR to transform practice in joint species distribution modeling of highly diverse groups, such as arthropods and fungi, since current methods fail to scale sufficiently to the sized datasets that are now being routinely collected.
