# Supplementary Material of "Factor pre-training in Bayesian multivariate LOGISTIC MODELS"
## A Proofs of the Main Results

Proof of Theorem 1. For a matrix $Z \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$, where $Z=\left\{z_{i j}\right\}_{i j}$, we denote by $\mathcal{L}(Z)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p} y_{i j} \log \left\{h^{-1}\left(z_{i j}\right)\right\}+$ $\left(1-y_{i j}\right) \log \left\{1-h^{-1}\left(z_{i j}\right)\right\}$, for brevity. Then, for $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ the solution to (5), consider the following decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y, X)-\log p\left(M_{0}, \Lambda_{0}, B_{0} \mid Y, X\right) \\
& =\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)+\log p(\hat{M})-\log p\left(M_{0}\right)+\log p(\hat{\Lambda})-\log p\left(\Lambda_{0}\right) \\
& +\log p(\hat{B})-\log p\left(B_{0}\right) \\
& =\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2}-\|\hat{M}\|_{F}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left\{\operatorname{tr}\left(\Lambda_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \Lambda_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{\Lambda}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \hat{\Lambda}\right)\right\} \\
& +\frac{1}{2}\left\{\operatorname{tr}\left(B_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} B_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{B}^{\top} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} \hat{B}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, $\log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y, X) \geq \log p\left(M_{0}, \Lambda_{0}, B_{0} \mid Y, X\right)$, we have

$$
\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)-\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z}) \leq \frac{1}{2}\left\|\left|M_{0}\right|\right\|_{F}^{2}-\|\hat{M}\|_{F}^{2}+\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{\Lambda}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \hat{\Lambda}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\Lambda_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \Lambda_{0}\right)+\operatorname{tr}\left(B_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} B_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{B}^{\top} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} \hat{B}\right)\right\|
$$

First, we consider the event with high probability where the infinity norm of $M_{0}$ and $X$ can be suitably bounded. Define the events

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A_{1}=\left\{\left\|\eta_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \log ^{1 / 2}(k n), i=1, \ldots, n\right\}=\left\{\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \log ^{1 / 2}(k n)\right\} \\
& A_{2}=\left\{\left\|x_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \leq c_{x} \log ^{1 / 2}(q n), i=1, \ldots, n\right\}=\left\{\|X\|_{\infty} \leq c_{x} \log ^{1 / 2}(q n)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

By corollary S1 and Assumption 5, we have $\operatorname{pr}\left(A_{1}\right)=\operatorname{pr}\left\{\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \log ^{1 / 2}(k n)\right\} \geq 1-\frac{2}{n}$ and $\operatorname{pr}\left(A_{2}\right)=1-C^{\prime} / n$. Next, we restrict our analysis to the event $A_{1} \cap A_{2}$. On the event $A_{1} \cap A_{2}$, and under Assumptions 3-5, we have

$$
\left\|Z_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \gamma_{n}, \quad\|\hat{Z}\|_{\infty} \leq \gamma_{n}, \quad \gamma_{n}=q c_{B} c_{X} \log ^{1 / 2}(q n)+2 k c_{\Lambda} \log ^{1 / 2}(k n) \leq \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left|M_{0}\right|\right\|_{F}^{2}-\|\hat{M}\|_{F}^{2}\right\| & \leq 4 k n \log (k n) \\
\left|\operatorname{tr}\left(\Lambda_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \Lambda_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{\Lambda}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \hat{\Lambda}\right)\right| & \leq \frac{2}{\tau_{\Lambda, m i n}^{2}} c_{\Lambda}^{2} k p \\
\left|\operatorname{tr}\left(B_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} B_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{B}^{\top} \Sigma_{B}^{-1} \hat{B}\right)\right| & \leq \frac{2}{\tau_{B, m i n}^{2}} c_{B}^{2} q p
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tau_{\lambda, \min }=\min \left\{\tau_{\lambda_{1}}, \ldots, \tau_{\lambda_{p}}\right\}$ and $\tau_{B, \min }=\min \left\{\tau_{\beta_{1}}, \ldots, \tau_{\beta_{p}}\right\}$. Moreover, letting $b(z)=\log \left(1+e^{z}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right) & =\sum_{i, j}\left\{y_{i j}\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)-\left\{b\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)-b\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}\right\} \\
& =\sum_{i, j}\left\{y_{i j}-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)-\left\{b\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)-b\left(z_{0 i j}\right)-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)\right\} \\
& =\sum_{i, j}\left\{y_{i j}-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)-\frac{1}{2} b^{\prime \prime}\left(\delta_{i j}\right)\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)^{2} \\
& \leq \sum_{i, j}\left\{y_{i j}-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \inf _{|\delta| \leq \gamma_{n}} b^{\prime \prime}(\delta)\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence,

$$
\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2} \leq 2\left\{\inf _{\mid \delta \mid \leq \gamma_{n}} b^{\prime \prime}(\delta)\right\}^{-1}\left[\sum_{i, j}\left\{y_{i j}-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)-\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)\right]
$$

Next, consider the following bound

$$
\sum_{i, j}\left\{y_{i j}-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{z}_{i j}-z_{0 i j}\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left\{\Psi^{\top}\left(\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right)\right\} \leq\|\Psi\|_{2}\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F} \operatorname{rank}\left(\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right)
$$

where $[\Psi]_{i j}=y_{i j}-b^{\prime}\left(z_{0 i j}\right)$. Note that $b^{\prime \prime}(\delta)=\frac{e^{\delta}}{1+e^{\delta}} \frac{1}{1+e^{\delta}}$, and $\inf _{|\delta| \leq \gamma_{n}} b^{\prime \prime}(\delta) \geq \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{1+e^{\gamma_{n}}}$. Hence, we get

$$
\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2} \leq 2\left(1+e^{\gamma_{n}}\right)\left\{\sqrt{2(k+q)}\|\Psi\|_{2}\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}+2 k n \log (k n)+\frac{1}{\tau_{\lambda, \min }^{2}} c_{\lambda}^{2} k p+\frac{1}{\tau_{B, \min }^{2}} c_{B}^{2} q p\right\}
$$

Notice, we can rewrite (S2) as a second-order inequality

$$
x^{2}-C_{1} x-C_{2} \leq 0
$$

where $C_{1}=2\left(1+e^{\gamma_{n}}\right) \sqrt{2(k+q)}\|\Psi\|_{2}, C_{2}=2\left(1+e^{\gamma_{n}}\right)\left\{2 k n \log (k n)+\frac{1}{\tau_{\lambda, \min }} c_{\lambda}^{2} k p+\frac{1}{\tau_{B, \min }} c_{B}^{2} q p\right\}$, and $x=$ $\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}$. The positive root for (S3) is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & =\frac{1}{2}\left(C_{1}+\sqrt{C_{1}^{2}+4 C_{2}}\right) \leq C_{1}+\sqrt{C_{2}} \\
& \leq 2\left(1+e^{\gamma_{n}}\right)\left\{\sqrt{2(k+q)}\|\Psi\|_{2}+\sqrt{2 k n \log (k n)}+\frac{1}{\tau_{\lambda, \min }^{2}} c_{\lambda} \sqrt{k p}+\frac{1}{\tau_{B, \min }^{2}} c_{B} \sqrt{q p}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we bound $\|\Psi\|_{2}$. By Lemma S4, with probability greater than $1-2 / n$, we have

$$
s_{1}(\Psi)=\|\Psi\|_{2} \leq n^{1 / 2}+C_{3} p^{1 / 2}+C_{4} \log ^{1 / 2}(n) \leq n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}
$$

where $C_{3}$ and $C_{4}$ are some constants not depending on $n$ and $p$. We define $A_{3}$ as the event where (S4) holds. Hence, under $A_{1} \cap A_{2} \cap A_{3}$, which has probability at least $1-\operatorname{pr}\left(A_{1}^{c}\right)-\operatorname{pr}\left(A_{2}^{c}\right)-\operatorname{pr}\left(A_{3}^{c}\right)=1-C / n$, where $C$ is an absolute constant,

$$
\frac{1}{(n p)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F} \leqslant e^{c \times \log ^{1 / 2}((k \vee q) n)}\left\{\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right\}
$$

proving the result in (16). Next, by Proposition S4, (19) and (20) follow. (18) follows from

$$
\left\|\hat{\Sigma}-\bar{\Lambda} \bar{\Lambda}^{\top}\right\|_{F}=\rho^{2}\|D\|_{F} \times p^{1 / 2} e^{c \times \log ^{1 / 2}((k \vee q) n)} \frac{1}{n}
$$

combined with an application of the triangle inequality. Finally, consider the following

$$
\left\|P_{\bar{U}}-P_{U_{0}}\right\|_{F}^{2}=2 k-2 \operatorname{tr}\left(P_{\bar{U}} P_{U_{0}}\right)=2\left\|\sin \left(\Theta_{\bar{U}, U_{0}}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}
$$

where $\bar{U}, U_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}$ are the matrices of left singular vectors of $\bar{M} \bar{\Lambda}^{\top}$ and $M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ respectively, $P_{W}$ denotes the orthogonal projection onto the column space of $W, P_{W}=W\left(W^{\top} W\right)^{-1} W^{\top}$, and $\sin \left(\Theta_{\bar{U}, U_{0}}\right)$ denote the sine of the angles between the subspaces spanned by $\bar{U}$ and $U_{0}$. Moreover, by Theorem 20 in O'Rourke et al. (2018), we have

$$
\sin \left(\Theta_{\bar{U}, U_{0}}\right) \leq 2 \frac{\left\|\bar{M} \bar{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{2}}{s_{k}\left(M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right)}
$$

Note that $s_{k}\left(M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right) \geq s_{k}\left(M_{0}\right) s_{k}\left(\Lambda_{0}\right) \gtrsim(n p)^{1 / 2}$ since $s_{k}\left(M_{0}\right) \gtrsim C_{5} n^{1 / 2}$ with probability $1-o(1)$ by Lemma S3. Hence,

$$
\left\|P_{\bar{U}}-P_{U_{0}}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{\left\|\bar{M} \bar{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{2}}{(n p)^{1 / 2}}
$$

proving (17). By Davis-Kahan theorem (Davis and Kahan, 1970) we have

$$
\min _{R \in R^{k \times k} ; R^{\top} R=I_{k}}\left\|\bar{U}-U_{0} R\right\|_{F}=\left\|\bar{U}-U_{0} \bar{R}\right\|_{F} \leq\left\|P_{\bar{U}}-P_{U_{0}}\right\|_{F}
$$

where $\bar{R}$ achieves the minimum on the left hand side. Consider the singular value decomposition of $M_{0}$, $\bar{U}_{0} D_{0} V_{0}^{\top}$, where $\bar{U}_{0}=U_{0} \bar{R}^{\top}$, for some orthogonal matrix $\bar{R} \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times k}$. Recalling that $\bar{M}=\sqrt{n} \bar{U}$ and letting $\bar{R}=\mathbf{V}_{0} \bar{R} \hat{R}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\bar{M}-M_{0} \bar{R}^{\top}\right\| & =\left\|\sqrt{n} \bar{U}-\bar{U}_{0} D_{0} V_{0}^{\top} \bar{R}\right\|=\left\|\sqrt{n} \bar{U}-U_{0} \bar{R}^{\top} D_{0} \bar{R} \bar{R}\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|\sqrt{n}\left(\bar{U}-U_{0} \bar{R}\right)\right\|+\left\|\sqrt{n} U_{0} \hat{R}-U_{0} \bar{R}^{\top} D_{0} \bar{R} \hat{R}\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|\sqrt{n}\left(\bar{U}-U_{0} \bar{R}\right)\right\|+\max _{1 \leq I \leq k_{0}}|\sqrt{n}-d_{0 I}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d_{0 l}$ is the $l$-th largest singular value of $D_{0}$. Moreover, by corollary 5.35 of Vershynin (2012), we have $\left|d_{0 l}-\sqrt{n}\right| \leq \sqrt{k_{0}}$ with probability at least $1-o(1)$. The result follows from all of the above.

Remark 3 (Note on the bound of Theorem 1). As discussed in the main paper, the bound in Theorem 1 is less tight than similar bounds in related works. This is due to different assumptions on latent factors and covariates. Notice the presence of $\left\{\inf _{\mid \delta \mid \leq \gamma_{n}} b^{\prime \prime}(\delta)\right\}^{-1}$ in (S1) where $\gamma_{n}$ is an upper bound to the absolute value of the linear predictor. Similarly, the constant in (S.2) in the proof of Lemma 1 of Lee et al. (2024) contains the same factor, and Theorem 1 in Davenport et al. (2014) presents the same term for a similar bound. As $\gamma_{n}$ diverges, we have $\left\{\inf _{\mid \delta \mid \leq \gamma_{n}} b^{\prime \prime}(\delta)\right\}^{-1} \times e^{\gamma_{n}}$, while $\left\{\inf _{\mid \delta \mid \leq \gamma_{n}} b^{\prime \prime}(\delta)\right\}^{-1}$ is bounded for any finite value of $\gamma_{n}$. Under the assumption $\eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right)$, combined with our assumption on $X$ (Assumption 5 of the main article), we can only bound the maximum of the absolute value of the linear predictor by some multiple of $\log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}$, which then determines the presence of the term $e^{c_{z} \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}$ in our results. Lee et al. (2024) assume covariates and latent factors fall in compact spaces that do not depend on $n$ and $p$ (Assumption 1 of Lee et al. (2024)). Consequently, they upper bound the absolute value of the linear predictor, and, in turn, upper and lower bound the second derivative of the log-partition function by a constant not dependent on $n$, which determines their sharper result. These assumptions in Lee et al. (2024) are restrictive in, for example, excluding cases in which covariates are independent samples from sub-Gaussian distributions. Moreover, even if the covariates are restricted to lie in some hypercube, assuming that latent factors are sampled as $\eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right)$, as is common in the literature on random factor analysis (West, 2003) and crucial for interpreting $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ as latent covariance between outcomes, induces a factor of $e^{c_{z} \log ^{1 / 2}(n)}$, since we can only bound the maximum of the absolute value of latent factors with some multiple of $\log ^{1 / 2}(k n)$ with high probability (Lemma S1). Finally, we note that, for $n \leq p_{n}$, our bound would be asymptotically dominated by $n^{-1 / 2+\epsilon}$, for any $\epsilon>0$, producing close to the parametric rate of convergence.

Proof of Theorem 2. To prove posterior contraction, we show that the posterior distribution for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $B$ contract around $\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}$ and $\tilde{B}$ respectively. Consider a sample for the posterior for $\Lambda$ and $B$. Due to the note on the posterior covariance (Section B.4), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\lambda_{j}-\tilde{\lambda}_{j}\right\| \leq \frac{e^{c_{z} / 2 \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}}{n^{1 / 2}} \log ^{1 / 2}(p), \\
& \left\|\beta_{j}-\beta_{j}\right\| \leq \frac{e^{c_{z} / 2 \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}}{n^{1 / 2}} \log ^{1 / 2}(p)
\end{aligned} \quad j=1, \ldots, p
$$

with posterior probability at least $1-2 / n$. Thus, with posterior probability at least $1-2 / n$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}-\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq \frac{e^{c_{z} / 2 \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}}{n^{1 / 2}} \log ^{1 / 2}(p) p \\
& \quad\|B-\tilde{B}\|_{F} \leq \frac{e^{c_{z} / 2 \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}}}{n^{1 / 2}} \log ^{1 / 2}(p)(p q)^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Lambda$ and $B$ are samples from $\hat{\Pi}$. An application of the triangle inequality combined with $\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \propto p$ proves the result.

# B Auxiliary Results and Lemmas
## B. 1 Auxiliary Results

Proposition S1 (Recovery of the factor analytic and linear predictor terms). Define $(\tilde{M}, \tilde{\Lambda}, \tilde{B})$ as the triplet obtained post-processing the joint maximum a posteriori estimate $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ solution to (5) via the procedure described in Section D.3. Under the same assumption of Theorem 1, with probability at least $1-o(1)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{\left(n p_{n}\right)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq \frac{\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}}{\left(n p_{n}\right)^{1 / 2}}+C_{1} \frac{k q}{n^{1 / 2}} \\
& \frac{1}{\left(n p_{n}\right)^{1 / 2}}\left\|X \tilde{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq \frac{\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}}{\left(n p_{n}\right)^{1 / 2}}+C_{2} \frac{k q}{n^{1 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ are universal constants not depending on $n, p$.
Proposition S2 (Recovery of the regression coefficients matrix $B_{0}$ ). If Assumption 5 holds,

$$
\left\|\tilde{B}-B_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq \frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}\left\|X \tilde{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}
$$

Proposition S3. If $\tilde{M}$ is such that $\tilde{M}^{\top} \tilde{M}=n I_{k}$, Assumptions 3, 4, 5 hold, and

$$
\frac{1}{\left(n p_{n}\right)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}\right\| \leq \delta_{n}
$$

with $\delta_{n} \rightarrow 0$ and $\delta_{n} \gtrsim n^{-1 / 2}$. Then, with probability at least $1-o(1)$, we have

$$
\frac{\left\|\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}}{\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}} \leq \delta_{n}
$$

Proposition S4. If $\tilde{M}$ is such that $\tilde{M}^{\top} \tilde{M}=n I_{k}$, Assumptions 3, 4, 5 hold,

$$
\frac{1}{\left(n p_{n}\right)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}\right\| \leq \delta_{n}
$$

with $\delta_{n} \rightarrow 0$ and $\delta_{n} \gtrsim n^{-1 / 2}$. Then, with probability at least $1-o(1)$,

$$
\frac{\left\|\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}}{\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}} \leq \delta_{n}, \quad \frac{1}{(p q)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\tilde{B}-B_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq \delta_{n}
$$

# B. 2 Proofs of Auxiliary Results 

Proof of Proposition S1. First, notice $\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}=\left(I-P_{X}\right) \hat{Z}$ and $M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}=\left(I-P_{X}\right) Z_{0}+P_{X} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$, where $P_{X}=$ $X\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1} X$. Similarly, $X \tilde{B}^{\top}=P_{X} \hat{Z}$ and $X B_{0}^{\top}=P_{X} Z_{0}-P_{X} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$. Thus, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} & =\left\|\left(I-P_{X}\right) \hat{Z}-\left(I-P_{X}\right) Z_{0}+P_{X} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \\
& \leq\left\|\left(I-P_{X}\right)\left(\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right)\right\|_{F}+\left\|P_{X} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \\
& \leq\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}+\left\|P_{X} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, consider $P_{X}=U_{X} U_{X}^{\top}$, where $U_{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times q}$ and $U_{X}^{\top} U_{X}=I_{q}$. Then, $\left\|P_{X} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}=\left\|U_{X}^{\top} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}$ and elements of $U_{X}^{\top} M_{0}$ are independent standard normal random variables. Hence, we have $\left\|U_{X}^{\top} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq$ $\left\|U_{X}^{\top} M_{0}\right\|_{F}\left\|\Lambda_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq k q p^{1 / 2}$ with probability $1-o(1)$, since $\left\|U_{X}^{\top} M_{0}\right\|_{F} \leq \sqrt{k q}$ with probability $1-o(1)$ by Lemma S2. With similar steps, we can obtain

$$
\frac{1}{(n p)^{1 / 2}}\left\|X \tilde{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq \frac{1}{(n p)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\hat{Z}-Z_{0}\right\|_{F}+\frac{k}{n^{1 / 2}}
$$

Proof of Proposition S2. The result follows from

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\hat{B}-B_{0}\right\|_{F} & =\left\|\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1} X^{\top}\left(X \hat{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right)\right\|_{F} \leq\left\|\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1} X^{\top}\right\|_{F}\left\|X \tilde{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \\
& \leq\left\|\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1}\right\|_{F}\|X\|_{F}\left\|X \tilde{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \\
& \leq \frac{k}{n^{1 / 2}}\left\|X \tilde{B}^{\top}-X B_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality follows from Assumption 5.
Proof of Proposition S3. Define $E=\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}-M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$. Then,

$$
\tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}=\frac{1}{n} \tilde{\Lambda} \tilde{M}^{\top} \tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}=\frac{1}{n}\left(\Lambda_{0} M_{0}^{\top} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}+E^{\top} E+E^{\top} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}+\Lambda_{0} M_{0}^{\top} E\right)
$$

and

$$
\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}=\frac{1}{n} \Lambda_{0} M_{0}^{\top} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}+\Lambda_{0}\left(I-\frac{1}{n} M_{0}^{\top} M_{0}\right) \Lambda_{0}^{\top}
$$

Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|E^{\top} E\right\|_{F} & \leq\|E\|_{F}^{2} \leq \delta_{n}^{2} n p \\
\left\|E^{\top} M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} & \leq\|E\|_{F}\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{2}\left\|\Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq \delta_{n} n p \\
\left\|\Lambda_{0}\left(I-\frac{1}{n} M_{0}^{\top} M_{0}\right) \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} & \leq\left\|\Lambda_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2}\left\|I-\frac{1}{n} M_{0}^{\top} M_{0}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|\Lambda_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2} \frac{\sqrt{k}}{n^{1 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

since, by Lemma S3, with probability $1-o(1)$, we have $\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{2} \leq n^{1 / 2}$ and $\left\|I-\frac{1}{n} M_{0}^{\top} M_{0}\right\|_{2} \leq \frac{k}{n^{1 / 2}}$. Thus,

$$
\left\|\overline{\Lambda} \overline{\Lambda}^{\top}-\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{F} \leq \delta_{n}^{2} p+\delta_{n} p+\left\|\Lambda_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2} \frac{\sqrt{k}}{n^{1 / 2}}
$$

The result follows from $\left\|\Lambda_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right\|_{2} \leqslant p$.

Proof of Proposition S4. Follows from Proposition S1, S2 and S3.

# B. 3 Auxiliary Lemmas 

Lemma S1 (Tail Probability of the Maximum of Sub-Gaussian Random Variables). Let $X_{i}$ be independent and identically distributed for $i=1, \ldots, n \sigma^{2}$-sub-Gaussian random variables. Then,

$$
p r\left[\max _{i=1, \ldots, n} X_{i}>\left[2 \sigma^{2}\{\log (n)+t\}\right]^{1 / 2}\right] \leq e^{-t}
$$

Proof Lemma S1. The result follows from

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(\max _{i=1, \ldots, n} X_{i}>u\right) \leq \sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{pr}\left(X_{i}>u\right) \leq n e^{-\frac{n^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}}}
$$

Corollary S1 (Corollary of Lemma S1). Letting $M_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}$, with $\left[M_{0}\right]_{i j} \sim N(0,1)$ independent,

$$
p r\left[\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{\infty}>\{2 \log (k n)+2 \log (n)\}^{1 / 2}\right] \leq 2 e^{-\log (n)}=\frac{2}{n}
$$

Lemma S2 (Lemma 1 of Laurent and Massart (2000) (Tail Probability of the Norm of a Gaussian Vector)). Consider $X \sim N_{p}(0, \Sigma)$, then

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(\|X\|_{2}^{2}>\operatorname{tr}(\Sigma)+2 \sqrt{t}\|\Sigma\|_{F}+2 t\|\Sigma\|_{2}\right) \leq e^{-t}
$$

Hence, for $X \sim N_{p}\left(0, \sigma^{2} I_{p}\right)$, then

$$
p r\left(\|X\|_{2}>t\right) \leq 2 \exp \left(-\frac{t^{2}}{2 p \sigma^{2}}\right)
$$

Corollary S2 (Corollary of Lemma S2). If $\eta_{t} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right)$ independently, then

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left\{\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \eta_{i}\right\|_{2}>(2 n k)^{1 / 2} \log ^{1 / 2}(n)\right\} \leq \frac{2}{n}
$$

Lemma S3 (Singular Values of Matrix with independent Gaussian Entries). Consider a matrix $X \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}$, such that $[X]_{i j} \sim N(0,1)$ independently, then

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left\{n^{1 / 2}-k^{1 / 2}-t \leq s_{d}(X) \leq s_{1}(X) \leq n^{1 / 2}+k^{1 / 2}+t\right\} \geq 1-2 e^{-t^{2} / 2}
$$

Proof of Lemma S3. See chapter 1 of Vershynin (2008).
Lemma S4 (Singular values of $\Psi$ ). Define the matrix $\Psi \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$, where $[\Psi]_{i j}=y_{i j}-h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{j}\right)$, where $\eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right)$ independently. Then, with probability at least $1-2 e^{-c t^{2}}$,

$$
s_{1}(\Psi) \leq n^{1 / 2}+C p^{1 / 2}+t
$$

where $c$ and $C$ are absolute constants.
Proof of Lemma S4. We modify the proof of Theorem 5.39 in Vershynin (2012) to matrices with independent rows and non-common diagonal second moment. We first condition on the realization of $M_{0}$ and consider it fixed. Next, we derive the conclusion since the desired result holds for every $M_{0}$. For $i=1, \ldots, n$ and $j=1, \ldots, p$, define $p_{i j}=h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{j}\right)$ and $v_{i j}=p_{i j}\left(1-p_{i j}\right)$, where, for simplicity, we dropped the dependence on the $\eta_{i}$ 's. Recall that conditionally on $M_{0}$, the elements of $\Psi$ are independent, and

$$
E\left(\Psi_{i j} \mid M_{0}\right)=0, \quad \operatorname{var}\left(\Psi_{i j} \mid M_{0}\right)=v_{i j}
$$

For $i=1, \ldots, n$, define $V_{i}=\operatorname{diag}\left(v_{i 1}, \ldots, v_{i p}\right)$ and $\bar{V}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} V_{i}$. Our conclusion is equivalent to showing

$$
\left\|\frac{1}{n} \Psi^{\top} \Psi-\bar{V}\right\| \leq \max \left(\delta, \delta^{2}\right)=\epsilon, \quad \delta=C \frac{p^{1 / 2}}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{t}{n^{1 / 2}}
$$

with high probability. Indeed, if (S5) holds, then for any $x \in S^{p-1}$, where $S^{p-1}$ denotes the unit sphere in $R^{p}$, $\left\|\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}} \Psi x\right\|^{2} \leq \epsilon+\left|x^{\top} \bar{V} x\right| \leq \epsilon+\frac{1}{4}$, which implies $\left\|\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}} \Psi x\right\| \leq \delta+\frac{1}{4}$, and, consequently, $s_{1}(\Psi) \leq \frac{n}{4}+C p^{1 / 2}+t$. Denote by $N$ a $1 / 4$-net of $S^{p-1}$, then, by Lemma 5.4 in Vershynin (2012), we have

$$
\left\|\frac{1}{n} \Psi^{\top} \Psi-\bar{V}\right\| \leq 2 \max _{x \in N}\left|\left\langle\left(\frac{1}{n} \Psi^{\top} \Psi-\bar{V}\right) x, x\right\rangle\right|=2 \max _{x \in N}\left|\frac{1}{n}\right||\Psi x||^{2}-x^{\top} \bar{V} x|
$$

It remains to show $\max _{x \in N}\left|\frac{1}{n}\right||\Psi x||^{2}-x^{\top} \bar{V} x\left| \leq \frac{\epsilon}{2}\right.$. By Lemma 5.2 in Vershynin (2012), we can choose $N$ to be of cardinality at most $9^{p}$. Fix a vector $x \in S^{p-1}$, and define $Z_{i}=\Psi_{i} x$, where $\Psi_{i}^{\top}$ is the $i$-th row of $\Psi$, then $||\Psi x||^{2}=\sum_{i}^{n} Z_{i}^{2}$. The $Z_{i}$ 's are independent, sub-Gaussian random variables with $E\left(Z_{i}^{2}\right)=x^{\top} V_{i} x \leq 1 / 4$ and $\left\|Z_{i}\right\|_{\#} \leq \max _{j}\left\|\Psi_{i j}\right\| \leq \frac{1}{\log (2)}$, where $\|X\|_{\#}$ denotes the sub-Gaussian norm of $X$. Hence, we have

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} Z_{i}^{2}-x^{\top} \bar{V} x\right|>\frac{\epsilon}{2}\right) \leq 2 \exp \left\{-c_{1} \min \left(\epsilon, \epsilon^{2}\right) N\right\} \leq 2 \exp \left(-c_{1} \delta^{2} N\right) \leq 2 \exp \left\{-c_{1}\left(C^{2} p+t^{2}\right)\right\}
$$

where the first inequality follows from Corollary 5.17 in Vershynin (2012), and $c_{1}=\frac{1}{32 e^{2} \log (2)}$. Thus,

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(\max _{x \in N}\left\{\frac{1}{n}| | \Psi x \mid\right|^{2}-x^{\top} \tilde{V} x \left\lvert\,>\frac{e}{2}\right.\right) \leq 9^{p} 2 \exp \left\{-c_{1}\left(C^{2} p+t^{2}\right)\right\} \leq 2 \exp \left(-c_{1} t^{2}\right)
$$

where the last inequality follows from choosing $C=\sqrt{\frac{\log (9)}{c_{1}}}$.

# B. 4 Note on the Posterior Variance 

Recall the posterior variance for $\theta_{j}$ is given by $\rho^{2} \tilde{V}_{j}$, where

$$
\tilde{V}_{j}=\left\{-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \theta_{j} \partial \theta_{j}^{\top}} p\left(Y^{(j)} \mid X, \tilde{M}, \lambda_{j}, \beta_{j}\right)+\log p\left(\lambda_{j}\left|\hat{\tau}_{3_{j}}\right)+\log p\left(\beta_{j}\left|\hat{\tau}_{\beta_{j}}\right|\right|_{\tilde{\theta}_{j}=\tilde{\theta}_{j}}\right\}^{-1}
$$

In the following, we assume $\tau_{\beta_{j}}=\mathcal{O}(1), \tau_{\lambda_{j}}=\mathcal{O}(1)$, and $\rho=\mathcal{O}(1)$. In particular, we have

$$
\tilde{V}_{j}^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
A+\tau_{\beta_{j}}^{-2} I_{q} & B \\
B^{\top} & C+\tau_{\lambda_{j}}^{-2} I_{k}
\end{array}\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} p_{i j}\left(1-p_{i j}\right) x_{i} x_{i}^{\top}=X^{\top} W_{j} X \\
B & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} p_{i j}\left(1-p_{i j}\right) x_{i} \tilde{q}_{i}^{\top}=X^{\top} W_{j} \tilde{M} \\
C & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} p_{i j}\left(1-p_{i j}\right) \tilde{q}_{i} \tilde{q}_{i}^{\top}=\tilde{M}^{\top} W_{j} \tilde{M}
\end{aligned}
$$

and $p_{i j}=h\left(\tilde{z}_{i j}\right)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-\gamma_{i j}}}, W_{j}=\operatorname{diag}\left(w_{j 1}, \ldots, w_{j n}\right)$, and $w_{j i}=p_{i j}\left(1-p_{i j}\right)$. Hence,

$$
V_{j}^{-1}=[X \tilde{M}]^{\top} W_{j}[X \tilde{M}]+\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\tau_{\beta_{j}}^{-2} I_{q} & 0 \\
0 & \tau_{\lambda_{j}}^{-2} I_{k}
\end{array}\right]
$$

Moreover,

$$
[X \tilde{M}]^{\top} W_{j}[X \tilde{M}] \geq w_{j, \min }[X \tilde{M}]^{\top}[X \tilde{M}]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
X^{\top} X & 0 \\
0 & n I_{k}
\end{array}\right]
$$

where $w_{j, \min }=\min \left\{w_{j 1}, \ldots, w_{j n}\right\}, w_{j, \min } \geq \frac{1}{2} h\left(-\gamma_{n}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{1+e^{\gamma_{n}}}$, and $\gamma_{n} \leq \log ^{1 / 2}\{(k \vee q) n\}$ is an upper bound to $\tilde{z}_{i j}$, and the equality follows from $\tilde{M}=n^{1 / 2} \tilde{U}$ with $\tilde{U}^{\top} \tilde{U}=I_{k}$ and $\tilde{M}^{\top} X=0$. Thus,

$$
V_{j} \leq 2\left(1+e^{\gamma_{n}}\right)\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1} & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{n} I_{k}
\end{array}\right]
$$

Recall that under Assumption 5, we have $\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1} \leq \frac{C}{n} I_{q}$, where $C$ is a universal constant. This implies that for a sample $\theta^{(x)}=\left(\theta_{1}^{(x)}, \ldots, \theta_{p}^{(x)}\right)$ from $\tilde{\Pi}$ we have $\theta_{j}^{(x)} \stackrel{\text { of }}{=} \tilde{\theta}_{j}+\rho \tilde{V}_{j}^{1 / 2} v_{j}$, with $v_{j} \sim N_{k+q}\left(0, I_{k+q}\right)$, where $\stackrel{\text { of }}{=}$ implies equality in distribution. Hence, we have

$$
\left\|\theta_{j}^{s}-\tilde{\theta}_{j}\right\|_{F} \leq e^{\gamma_{n} / 2} \frac{\log (p)}{n^{1 / 2}}
$$

for all $j=1, \ldots, p$, with posterior probability at least $1-o(1)$.

# C Extension to the Probit Model
## C. 1 Main Result

It is interesting to extend the results above to other models for binary data, for instance using the probit link $\Phi^{-1}(\cdot)$, where $\Phi(\cdot)$ denotes the cumulative distribution function of a standard normal random variable. The following Theorem shows that the joint maximum a posteriori estimates obtained under a probit link have asymptotic accuracy guarantees in approximating the true sample and outcome-specific probabilities in the large $p$ and $n$ regime.

Theorem S3 (Recovery of the distribution under the probit model). Suppose Assumptions 1 - 5 hold with $h(\cdot)$ replaced by $\Phi(\cdot)$ in equation (S13). Define $\hat{Z}=X \hat{B}^{\top}+\hat{M} \hat{\Lambda}^{\top}$, where $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ is the solution to (5), with the probit likelihood replacing the logistic one, then, with probability at least $1-C / n$

$$
d_{H}^{2}\left\{\Phi(\hat{Z}), \Phi\left(Z_{0}\right)\right\} \leq \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\left(\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{1}{p_{n}^{1 / 2}}\right)
$$

where $d_{H}^{2}\left\{\Phi(\hat{Z}), \Phi\left(Z_{0}\right)\right\}=\frac{1}{n p} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p_{n}} d_{H}^{2}\left\{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right), \Phi\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}, d_{H}^{2}(f, g)=(\sqrt{f}-\sqrt{g})^{2}+(\sqrt{1-f}-\sqrt{1-g})^{2}$, and $C$ is a universal constant not depending on $n$ and $p_{n}$.

Remark 4. The same bound can be derived for the Kullback-Leibler divergence $\mathcal{D}\{\Phi(Z) \| \Phi(\hat{Z})\}=$ $\frac{1}{n p} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left\{\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right) \log \left\lfloor\frac{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)}{\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)}\right\rfloor+\left\{1-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)\right\} \log \left\{\frac{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)}{1-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)}\right\}\right\}$ and the squared total variation distance $d_{T V}^{2}\left\{\Phi(\hat{Z}), \Phi(Z)\right\}=\frac{1}{n p} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left|\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)\right|^{2}$.

It would be appealing to modify the result in Theorem S3 to bound the norm of $\hat{Z}-Z$, as in (16). However, this is not trivial due to the flatness of the probit likelihood in the tails. However, our preliminary numerical results show that our method performs extremely well in the probit case; formally justifying this performance theoretically including for broader classes of link functions is an interesting area for future research.

# C. 2 Proof of Theorem S3 

Proof of Theorem S3. We follow the proof of Theorem 2 in Davenport et al. (2014) with three modifications: firstly, $M_{0}$, and, hence, $Z_{0}$ are not fixed but random, secondly, we consider a general design matrix $X$, and, thirdly, we consider the joint maximum a posteriori estimate under truncated Gaussian priors instead of the joint maximum likelihood estimate. Consider the difference between the log-posterior computed at the joint maximum a posteriori estimate and true parameter respectively. For a matrix $Z \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$, where $[Z]_{i j}=z_{i j}$, with a slight abuse of notation, we redefine $\mathcal{L}(Z)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p} y_{i j} \log \left\{\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)\right\}+\left(1-y_{i j}\right) \log \left\{1-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)\right\}$, which is the log-likelihood under the probit link function. Recall the decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y, X)-\log p\left(M_{0}, \Lambda_{0}, B_{0} \mid Y, X\right) \\
& =\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)+\log p(\hat{M})-\log p\left(M_{0}\right)+\log p(\hat{\Lambda})-\log p\left(\Lambda_{0}\right) \\
& +\log p(\hat{B})-\log p\left(B_{0}\right) \\
& =\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\|M_{0}\right\|_{F}^{2}-\|\hat{M}\|_{F}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left\{\operatorname{tr}\left(\Lambda_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \Lambda_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{\Lambda}^{\top} \Sigma_{\Lambda}^{-1} \hat{\Lambda}\right)\right\} \\
& +\frac{1}{2}\left\{\operatorname{tr}\left(B_{0}^{\top} \Sigma_{\hat{B}}^{-1} B_{0}\right)-\operatorname{tr}\left(\hat{B}^{\top} \Sigma_{\hat{B}}^{-1} \hat{B}\right)\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

With the same steps of the Proof for Theorem 1, we obtain

$$
\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)-\mathcal{L}(\tilde{Z}) \leq n \log (k n)+(k+q) p
$$

with probability at least $1-C / n$ for some absolute constant $C$. Define $\tilde{\mathcal{L}}(Z)=\mathcal{L}(Z)-\mathcal{L}(0)$, and consider the following expectation

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left(\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right) \mid M_{0}\right) & =E\left(\tilde{\mathcal{L}}(\hat{Z})-\tilde{\mathcal{L}}\left(Z_{0}\right) \mid M_{0}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p} E\left(y_{i j} \log \left\{\frac{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)}{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)}\right\}-\left(1-y_{i j}\right) \log \left\{\frac{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)}{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)}\right\} \mid M_{0}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left\{\Phi\left(z_{0 i j}\right) \log \left\{\frac{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)}{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)}\right\}-\left\{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)\right\} \log \left\{\frac{1-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)}{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)}\right\}\right\} \\
& =-n p \mathcal{D}\left\{\Phi\left(Z_{0}\right) \| \Phi(\hat{Z})\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{D}\left\{\Phi\left(Z_{0}\right) \| \Phi(\hat{Z})\right\}=\frac{1}{n p} \sum_{i, j} \Phi\left(z_{0 i j}\right) \log \left\{\frac{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{i j}\right)}{\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)}\right\}-\left\{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)\right\} \log \left\{\frac{1-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)}{1-\Phi\left(\hat{z}_{0 i j}\right)}\right\}$ denotes the average KL divergence across rows and columns. Next, consider the following decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right) & =E\left(\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right) \mid M_{0}\right)+\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z})-E\left\{\mathcal{L}(\hat{Z}) \mid M_{0}\right\}-\left[\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right)-E\left(\mathcal{L}\left(Z_{0}\right) \mid M_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \leq-n p \mathcal{D}\left\{\Phi\left(Z_{0}\right) \| \Phi(\hat{Z})\right\}+2 \sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}\left|\mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{G}=\left\{Z: \operatorname{rank}(Z)=k+q \quad\|Z\|_{\infty} \leq \gamma_{n}\right\}$, since $Z_{0}, \hat{Z} \in \mathcal{G}$. Combining all the above, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log p(\hat{\mu}, \hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda} \mid Y)-\log p\left(\mu_{0}, M_{0}, \Lambda_{0} \mid Y\right) \\
& \quad \leq-n p \mathcal{D}\left\{\Phi\left(Z_{0}\right) \| \Phi(\hat{Z})\right\}+2 \sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}|\mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)|+C_{2}\{k n \log (k n)+(k+q) p\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some absolute constant $C_{2}$, and, since $\log p(\hat{\mu}, \hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda} \mid Y)-\log p\left(\mu_{0}, M_{0}, \Lambda_{0} \mid Y\right) \geq 0$, we obtain

$$
\mathcal{D}\left\{\Phi\left(Z_{0}\right) \| \Phi(\hat{Z})\right\} \leq \frac{1}{n p} 2 \sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}|\mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)|+C_{2}\{k n \log (k n)+(k+q) p\}
$$

To bound the first term on the right hand side of (C.2), we rely on Lemma S5. In particular, we first define $A_{4}=\left\{\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}|\mathcal{L}(Z)-E\{\mathcal{L}(Z)\}| \geq C_{0} \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right)\right\}$. By Lemma S5, conditionally on the realization of $M_{0}$, we have

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left[\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid \geq C_{0} \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right) \mid M_{0}\right] \leq \frac{1}{n+p}
$$

Importantly, $C_{0}$ is an absolute constant not depending on the realization of $M_{0}$. This implies that $\operatorname{pr}\left(A_{4}\right) \leq$ $1-1 /(n+p)$. On the event $A_{1} \cap A_{2} \cap A_{4}$, we have

$$
\mathcal{D}\left\{\Phi\left(Z_{0}\right) \mid \Phi(\hat{Z})\right\} \leq \log \{(k \vee q) n\}(k+q)^{1 / 2}\left(\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}}+\frac{1}{p^{1 / 2}}\right)+\frac{4}{p} k \log (k n)+\frac{2}{n} c_{4}^{2} k
$$

To conclude note that $\operatorname{pr}\left[A_{1} \cap A_{2} \cap A_{4}\right] \geq 1-\frac{2}{n}-\frac{C_{1}}{n+p}-\frac{1}{n+p}$ and recall $d_{H}^{2}(p, q) \leq \mathcal{D}(p \| q)$ and $d_{T V}^{2}(p, q) \leq \mathcal{D}(p \| q)$, where $d_{H}^{2}\left\{\Phi(\hat{Z}), \Phi\left(Z_{0}\right)\right\}=\frac{1}{n p} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p_{n}} d_{H}^{2}\left\{\Phi\left(\xi_{i j}\right), \Phi\left(z_{0 i j}\right)\right\}$, with $d_{H}^{2}(f, g)=$ $(\sqrt{f}-\sqrt{g})^{2}+(\sqrt{1-f}-\sqrt{1-g})^{2}$, is the average Hellinger distance squared, and $d_{T V}^{2}\{\Phi(\hat{Z}), \Phi(Z)\}=$ $\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left|\Phi\left(\xi_{i j}\right)-\Phi\left(z_{i j}\right)\right|^{2}$ is the average squared total variation distance.

Lemma S5. Consider the following set

$$
\mathcal{G}=\left\{Z \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}: \operatorname{rank}(Z)=k+q, \quad\|Z\|_{\infty} \leq \gamma_{n}\right\}
$$

Then,

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left[\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid \geq C_{0} \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right) \mid M_{0}\right] \leq \frac{1}{n+p}
$$

where $C_{0}$ is an absolute constant.

Proof of Lemma 55. The proof is similar to the one of Lemma 1 in Davenport et al. (2014). We start by a straightforward application of the Markov inequality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{pr}\left[\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid \geq C_{0} \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right) \mid M_{0}\right] \\
& =\operatorname{pr}\left[\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid^{h} \geq\left[C_{0} \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right)\right]^{h} \mid M_{0}\right] \\
& \leq \frac{E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid^{h} \mid M_{0}\right)}{\left[C_{0} \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right)\right]^{h}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid^{h} \mid M_{0}\right)=E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \tilde{\mathcal{L}}(Z)-E\left(\tilde{\mathcal{L}}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)\right]^{h} \mid M_{0}$ ), and, by a symmetrization argument,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \tilde{\mathcal{L}}(Z)-E\left(\tilde{\mathcal{L}}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)\right]^{h} \mid M_{0} \text { ) } \\
& \quad \leq 2^{h} E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}\left|\sum_{i j} \varepsilon_{i j}\right| 1_{\left\{y_{i j}=1\right\}} \log \left\{\frac{\Phi\left(Z_{i j}\right)}{\Phi(0)}\right\}-1_{\left\{y_{i j}=0\right\}} \log \left\{\left.\frac{1-\Phi\left(Z_{i j}\right)}{1-\Phi(0)}\right\}\right\}\right|^{h} \mid M_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the $\varepsilon_{i j}$ 's are independent Rademacher random variables and now the expectation is taken over $Y$ and also the $\varepsilon_{i j}$ 's. For $|z| \in \gamma_{n}$, the functions $\frac{1}{L_{\gamma_{n}}} \log \left\{\frac{\Phi(z)}{\Phi(0)}\right\}$ and $\frac{1}{L_{\gamma_{n}}} \log \left\{\frac{1-\Phi(z)}{1-\Phi(0)}\right\}$ are contractions vanishing at 0 , where $L_{\gamma}=\sup _{|z| \leq \gamma} \frac{\left|\Phi^{\prime}(z)\right|}{\Phi(z)\{1-\Phi(z)\}} \leq 8(\gamma+1)$. Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right) \mid^{h} \mid M_{0}\right) & \leq 2^{h}\left(2 L_{\gamma_{n}}\right)^{h} E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p} \varepsilon_{i j}\left(1_{\left\{y_{i j}=1\right\}} Z_{i j}-1_{\left\{y_{i j}=0\right\}} Z_{i j}\right)\right|^{h} \mid M_{0}\right) \\
& \leq 2^{h}\left(2 L_{\gamma_{n}}\right)^{h} E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}|(E, Z)|^{h} \mid M_{0}\right) \\
& =\left(4 L_{\gamma_{n}}\right)^{h} E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}|(E, Z)|^{h}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $[E]_{i j}=\varepsilon_{i j}$. Moreover, since $|(A, B)| \leq| | A| || | B \mid \mid$,,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}|(E, Z)|^{h}\right) & \leq E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}| | E| ||^{h}| | Z| ||^{h}\right) \\
& \leq \sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}}| | Z| |_{*} E\left(| | E| ||^{h}\right) \\
& \leq[n p(k+q) \log \{(k \vee q) n\}]^{h / 2}\left(n^{\frac{h}{2}}+p^{\frac{h}{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used,

$$
E\left(\|E\|^{h}\right) \leq C\left(n^{\frac{h}{2}}+p^{\frac{h}{2}}\right)
$$

by Theorem 1 of Seginer (2000), and

$$
\|Z\|_{*} \leq(n p)^{1 / 2} \operatorname{rank}^{1 / 2}(Z)\|Z\|_{\infty} \leq\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2} \gamma_{n} \leq[n p(k+q) \log \{(k \vee q) n\}]^{1 / 2}
$$

for sufficiently large $n$. Thus, we get

$$
E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)\left.\right|^{h} \mid M_{0}\right)^{1 / h} \leq \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

Taking $C$ sufficiently large, and $h=\log (n+p)$ delivers

$$
\frac{E\left(\sup _{Z \in \mathcal{G}} \mid \mathcal{L}(Z)-E\left(\mathcal{L}(Z) \mid M_{0}\right)\left.\right|^{h} \mid M_{0}\right)}{[C \log \{(k \vee q) n\}\{n p(k+q)\}^{1 / 2}\left(n^{1 / 2}+p^{1 / 2}\right)]^{h}} \leq \hat{C}^{\log (n+p)} \leq \frac{1}{n+p}
$$

# D Details on the Optimization Procedure
## D. 1 Singular Value Decomposition based Initialization

We initialize the optimization routine with the values obtained adapting the estimation procedure in (Chen et al., 2019) to the general design matrix $X$ case:

1. We compute the singular value decomposition of $Y=U_{\hat{k}} D_{\hat{k}} V_{\hat{k}}^{\mathrm{T}}+U_{-\hat{k}} D_{-\hat{k}} V_{-\hat{k}}^{\mathrm{T}}$, where $\hat{k}=k+q$, and let $\hat{Y}=U_{\hat{k}} D_{\hat{k}} V_{\hat{k}}^{\mathrm{T}}$ be the $\hat{k}$-rank approximation to $Y$.
2. We compute $\hat{Y}=\left[\hat{y}_{i j}\right]_{i j}$ by applying the following thresholding operator entry-wise to $\hat{Y}=\left[\hat{y}_{i j}\right]_{i j}$,

$$
\hat{y}_{i j}= \begin{cases}\epsilon_{n, p} & \text { if } \hat{y}_{i j}<\epsilon_{n, p} \\ \hat{y}_{i j} & \text { if } \hat{y}_{i j} \in\left[\epsilon_{n, p}, 1-\epsilon_{n, p}\right] \\ 1-\epsilon_{n, p} & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

3. We compute the matrix $\hat{Z}$ by applying the function $h^{-1}(\cdot)$ entry-wise to $\hat{Y}$,
4. We initialize $B$ via $\hat{B}=Z^{\mathrm{T}} X\left(X^{\mathrm{T}} X\right)^{-1}$,
5. We define $\hat{Z}^{c}$ as $\hat{Z}^{c}=\hat{Z}-X \hat{B}^{\mathrm{T}}$, compute the singular value decomposition of $\hat{Z}^{c}=L_{k} S_{k} R_{k}^{\mathrm{T}}+L_{-k} S_{-k} R_{-\hat{k}}^{\mathrm{T}}$, and initialize the factors via $\hat{M}=n^{1 / 2} L_{k}$ and loadings via $\hat{\Lambda}=\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}} R_{k} S_{k}$.

This method was initially proposed in Chen et al. (2019) for the case where $X=1_{n}$, and Zhang et al. (2020) showed this produces consistent estimates for the loadings. Here, we report a heuristic argument:

1. $\hat{Y} \approx E(Y)=P=\left[\operatorname{pr}\left(y_{i j}=1 \mid \eta_{i}, \lambda_{0 j}, x_{i}, \beta_{j}\right)\right]_{i j}=\left[h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{0 j}\right)\right]_{i j}$ in a mean-squared sense as $n, p \rightarrow \infty$, hence $\hat{y}_{i j} \approx P_{i j}=h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{0 j}\right)$ on average across rows and columns.
2. We ensure $\hat{y}_{i j} \in\left[\epsilon_{n, p}, 1-\epsilon_{n, p}\right]$, so that we can treat $\hat{y}_{i j}$ as a valid estimate of a probability and "invert" it in Step 3.
3. From Step 1 and 2, we have $\bar{y}_{i j} \approx h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{0 j}\right)$, hence, $\hat{z}_{i j}=h^{-1}\left(\bar{Y}_{i j}\right) \approx x_{i}^{\top} \beta_{j}+\eta_{i}^{\top} \lambda_{0 j}$, thus, $\hat{X}=h^{-1}(\bar{Y}) \approx X B_{0}^{\top}+M_{0} \Lambda_{0 j}^{\top}$.
4. Since $\hat{X} \approx X B_{0}^{\top}+M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ and $\left(I-P_{\hat{X}}\right) \hat{X}=L_{k} S_{k} R_{k}^{\top}+L_{-k} S_{-k} R_{-k}^{\top}$, then $\sqrt{n} L_{k} \approx M_{0}$ and $\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}} R_{k} S_{k} \approx \Lambda_{0}$ up to orthogonal rotations,
5. Similarly, since $\hat{Z} \approx X B_{0}^{\top}+M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}$ and $E\left(X^{\top} M_{0}\right)=0, \hat{B}^{\top} \approx\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1} X^{\top}\left(X B_{0}^{\top}+M_{0} \Lambda_{0}^{\top}\right) \approx B_{0}$.

This choice for the initialization of the optimization routine guarantees that the initial values for $(M, \Lambda, B)$ are close to a local mode speeding up the convergence. When $n$ and $p$ are very large, we optionally replace the singular value decomposition with a randomized version (Halko et al., 2011; Erichson et al., 2019). This considerably speeds-up initialization with negligible impact on the final solution of the algorithm.

# D. 2 Projected Newton-Raphson Ascent 

Each subproblem of (7) and (8) is solved via projected Newton ascent. More specifically, for (7), we maximize the log-posterior for $\theta_{j}=\left(\beta_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$, given the previous estimate for $M, \hat{M}$. This is equivalent to finding maximum a posterior estimate for the regression coefficients of $p$ logistic regressions using the concatenation of $X$ and $\hat{M}$ and the $Y^{(j)}$ 's as the outcome, where $Y^{(j)}$ denotes the $j$-th column of $Y$. This is solved via projected Newton ascent, that is, given the current value of the parameter $\theta_{j}^{(t)}$ we update via

$$
\theta_{j}^{(t+1) *} \leftarrow \theta_{j}^{(t)}-\left.v \nabla_{\theta_{j} \theta_{j}^{\top}}^{2} \log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y)\right|_{\theta_{j}=\theta_{j}^{(t)}} ^{-1} \nabla_{\theta_{j}} \log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y) \|_{q_{j}=\theta_{j}^{(t)}}
$$

and

$$
\theta_{j}^{(t+1)} \leftarrow T_{1}\left(\theta_{j}^{(t+1) *}\right)
$$

where $T_{1}(x)$ projects $x$ to the constraint set for the $\theta_{j}$ 's defined by the problem. We set the step-size to the default value of $v=0.3$, which worked well in both simulated and real data examples.

Similarly, for (8), we maximize the log-posterior over $\eta_{i}$, given the estimates for $\Lambda$ and $B, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$. Similarly as above, this operation can be parallelized across rows and at each iteration let

$$
\eta_{i}^{(t+1) *} \leftarrow \eta_{i}^{(t)}-\left.v \nabla_{\eta_{i} \eta_{j}^{\top}}^{2} \log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y)\right|_{\eta_{i}=\eta_{i}^{(t)}} ^{-1} \nabla_{\eta_{i}} \log p(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B} \mid Y) \|_{q_{i}=\eta_{i}^{(t)}}
$$

and

$$
\eta_{i}^{(t+1)} \leftarrow T_{2}\left(\eta_{i}^{(t+1)^{*}}\right)
$$

where $T_{2}(x)$ projects $x$ to the constraint set for the $\eta_{i}$ 's defined by the problem. We set the step-size to the default value of $v=1$, which worked well in both simulated and real data examples.

We stop the algorithm when the Euclidean norm of the update is smaller than some small threshold, which we set to the default value of 0.001 . To optimize (6), we alternate between (7) and (8) until the relative increase in the log-posterior is smaller than a small threshold, which we set by default to 0.001 .

Our current implementation uses for loops to iterate steps in (S8) and S10, but these steps could be parallelized across columns $(j=1, \ldots, p)$ and rows $(i=1, \ldots, n)$ of $Y$ to produce substantial gains in computational speed. Not all of the competitors are similarly parallelizable.

# D. 3 Post-Processing Procedure 

We borrow the post-processing procedure from Chen et al. (2019) and adapt it to the case of a general design matrix $X$. In particular, we transform the $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ solution from (5) to $(\hat{M}, \hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$, through the following operations.

1. Compute $\hat{M}^{c}=\hat{M}-P_{X} \hat{M}$, where $P_{A}=A\left(A^{\top} A\right)^{-1} A^{\top}$, and apply the singular value decomposition to $\hat{M}^{c}=U D V^{\top}$,
2. Set $\tilde{M}=n^{1 / 2} U$ and $\tilde{\Lambda}=\frac{1}{n^{1 / 2}} \tilde{\Lambda} V$,
3. Set $\hat{B}=\hat{B}+\hat{\Lambda} \hat{M}^{\top} X\left(X^{\top} X\right)^{-1}$.

It is easy to verify that $(\tilde{M}, \tilde{\Lambda}, \tilde{B})$ satisfies the following properties

1. $\hat{M} \hat{\Lambda}^{\top}+X \hat{B}^{\top}=\tilde{M} \tilde{\Lambda}^{\top}+X \tilde{B}^{\top}$,
2. $\hat{M}^{\top} \tilde{M}=n I_{k}$,
3. $\hat{M}^{\top} X=0$.

## E Hyperparameter Selection
## E. 1 Variance Parameters

We highlight a data-driven strategy to select the hyperparameters $\tau_{B}=\left(\tau_{\beta_{1}}, \ldots, \tau_{\beta_{p}}\right)$ and $\tau_{\Lambda}=\left(\tau_{\lambda_{1}}, \ldots, \tau_{\lambda_{p}}\right)$. In particular, given the initial values of $(\hat{\Lambda}, \hat{B})$ obtained with the procedure described in Section D.1, we set $\tau_{\lambda_{j}}$ to $\hat{\tau}_{\lambda_{j}}=\mathcal{T}\left(k^{-1 / 2}\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right\|\right)$ and $\tau_{\beta_{j}}$ to $\hat{\tau}_{\beta_{j}}=\mathcal{T}\left(k^{-1 / 2}\left\|\hat{\beta}_{j}\right\|\right)$, where $\mathcal{T}$ is a hard-truncation operator such that $\mathcal{T}(x)=x 1_{\{x \in(l, u)\}}+l 1_{\{x \leq l\}}+u 1_{\{x \geq u\}}$ and $l=0.5, u=20$. This strategy is appealing since it does not require

any manual tuning and showed good performance across a wide range of examples. Clearly, other choices including posterior predictive checks or cross-validation maximizing the likelihood on a hold out set are equally viable but can be computationally more expensive.

# E. 2 Calibration of $\rho$ 

We calibrate the variance inflation factor $\rho$ by choosing $\rho=\max _{1 \leq j, j^{\prime} \leq p} b_{j j^{\prime}}$ with

$$
b_{j j^{\prime}}= \begin{cases}\left\{1+\frac{\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j^{\prime}}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}^{\top} \hat{\lambda}_{j^{\prime}}\right)^{2}}{\sigma_{j^{\prime}}^{2}\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\sigma_{j}^{\top}\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j^{\prime}}\right\|_{2}^{2}}\right\}^{1 / 2} & \text { if } j \neq j^{\prime} \\ \left(1+\frac{\left\|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right\|_{2}^{2}}{2 \sigma_{j}^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2} & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where $\tilde{\sigma}_{j}^{2}=1.702^{2}+\frac{n}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \hat{\rho}_{i}+\hat{\eta}_{i}^{\top} \hat{\lambda}_{i}\right)\left\{1-h\left(x_{i}^{\top} \hat{\rho}_{i}+\hat{\eta}_{i}^{\top} \hat{\lambda}_{i}\right)\right\}}$. This choice is inspired by Chattopadhyay et al. (2024). Here, we provide a heuristic justification. Considering $Y$ as the dichotomization of a latent continuous matrix $Y^{*}$, we have $y_{i j}=1_{\left\{y_{i j}^{*}>0\right\}}, i=1, \ldots, n, j=1, \ldots, p$, where the matrix $Y^{*}=\left[y_{i j}^{*}\right]_{i j}$ is

$$
Y^{*}=X B^{\top}+M \Lambda^{\top}+E, \quad E=\left[\epsilon_{i j}\right]_{i j}, \quad \epsilon_{i j} \sim f
$$

and $f$ is a logistic density, that is $f(x)=h^{\prime}(x)$ with $h(\cdot)$ being the logistic cumulative density function. Since $\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}}|h(x)-\Phi(x / 1.702)| \leq 0<0.0095$ (Bowling et al., 2009), we approximate the $\epsilon_{i j}$ 's via a normally distributed random variable as $\epsilon_{i j} \approx 1.702 \varepsilon_{i j}$ where $\varepsilon_{i j} \sim N(0,1)$ independently. Defining $\tilde{E}=\tilde{Z}-Y^{*}$, we have

$$
\tilde{Z} \approx X B^{\top}+M \Lambda^{\top}+1.702 E+\tilde{E}, \quad E=\left[\varepsilon_{i j}\right]_{i j}, \quad \varepsilon_{i j} \sim N(0,1)
$$

Chattopadhyay et al. (2024) consider the case of Gaussian distributed data without covariates and estimate the latent factors as the leading left singular vectors of the data scaled by $n^{1 / 2}$. The authors showed that defining the coefficients $\left\{b_{j j^{\prime}}\right\}$ as (S12), where $\hat{\lambda}_{j}$ is the posterior mean of $\lambda_{j}, \tilde{\sigma}_{j}$ estimates the standard deviation of the columns of the residual matrix, and choosing $\rho=\max _{j, j^{\prime}} b_{j j^{\prime}}$ guarantees asymptotic correct frequentist coverage. Thus, considering the analogy developed above, since $\tilde{M}$ corresponds to the left singular values of $\tilde{Z}$, after regressing out the covariate effects, scaled by $n^{1 / 2}$ (up to rotation), we apply the coverage correction strategy from Chattopadhyay et al. (2024), treating the $\hat{\lambda}_{j}$ 's as if they were the regression coefficient from regressing $\tilde{M}$ on $\tilde{Z}$. As a final step, we approximate the elements $\tilde{E}$ as independent normal random variables. Consider the negative Hessian of the log-likelihood for the $i$-th row and $j$-th column with respect to $\theta_{j}$

$$
-\nabla_{\theta_{j}}^{2} \log p\left(y_{i j} \mid-\right)=h\left(\tilde{z}_{i j}\right)\left\{1-h\left(\tilde{z}_{i j}\right)\right\} \tilde{x}_{i} \tilde{x}_{i}^{\top}
$$

where $\tilde{x}_{i}=\left(x_{i}^{\top} \tilde{\eta}_{i}^{\top}\right)^{\top}$ and $\tilde{z}_{i j}=x_{i}^{\top} \tilde{\beta}_{j}+\tilde{\eta}_{i}^{\top} \tilde{\lambda}_{j}$. Thus, we can interpret $h\left(\tilde{z}_{i j}\right)\left\{1-h\left(\tilde{z}_{i j}\right)\right\}$ as a proxy for the precision for the estimator from the $i$-th observation for the $j$-th outcome. Hence, we estimate the variance of

the $j$-th column of $\hat{E}$ as the inverse of the average of the precision proxies, that is $\frac{n}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} h\left(z_{j}\right)\left\{1-h\left(z_{j}\right)\right\}}$, and set $\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{2}=1.702^{2}+\frac{n}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} h\left(x_{i}^{+} \hat{\rho}_{i}+\bar{\eta}_{i}^{+} \hat{\lambda}_{i}\right)\left\{1-h\left(x_{i}^{+} \hat{\rho}_{i}+\bar{\eta}_{i}^{+} \hat{\lambda}_{i}\right)\right\}}$.

Our derivation for $\rho$ is based on the representation of binary variables as truncated latent continuous variables with logistic density. Similarly, an analogous approach could be derived for Bernoulli responses with the probit link, whereas extensions to other GLLVMs are less straightforward.

We conducted a simulation study to test the performance of FLAIR in a lower dimensional scenario. In particular, we simulate data from model (S13), where parameters are generated as follows

for $j=1, \ldots, p, l=1, \ldots, k, l^{\prime}=1, \ldots, q$, and $T N\left(\mu, \sigma^{2}, a, b\right)$ denotes a truncated normal distribution with mean $\mu$, variance $\sigma^{2}$, and support $(a, b)$. (2017), GLLVM-LA) and an extended variational approximation (Korhonen et al. (2022), GLLVM-EVA) as implemented in the gllvm R package. Table S1 reports a comparison in terms of estimation accuracy and computational time. Even in lower dimensional examples FLAIR compares favorably to competitors in many scenarios. Table S2 provides additional evidence of the frequentist validity of FLAIR credible intervals; these intervals had valid frequentist coverage on average over entries of $B$ and $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ for $p \geq 100$ while suffering only a mild under-coverage for $p=50$. In contrast, GLLVM-LA suffers from undercoverage, and GLLVM-EVA provides valid uncertainty quantification for $B$ but not for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$.

# F. 2 Longitudinal Scenarios 

We present some experiments in longitudinal scenarios. In particular, we compare with Lee et al. (2024) (LVHML, henforth), implemented using the code at https://github.com/Arthurlee51/LVHML. As discussed in the introduction, LVHML assumes latent factors to be fixed constants. Therefore, we cannot directly estimate the latent covariance between outcomes with $\hat{\Lambda} \hat{\Lambda}^{\top}$. In fact, the latent covariance between species implied by model (S13) is given by $\Lambda \operatorname{cov}\left(\eta_{i}\right) \Lambda^{\top}$, which reduces to $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ in (2), since $\operatorname{cov}\left(\eta_{i}\right)=I_{k}$ as we assumed $\eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right)$. To remedy this and estimate the latent covariance $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ in (2) for LVHML, we use $\hat{\Lambda}\left(\hat{M}^{\top} \hat{M}\right) / n \hat{\Lambda}^{\top}$, which is obtained by replacing $\operatorname{cov}\left(\eta_{i}\right)$ by the empirical covariance of estimates for latent factors, where $\hat{M}$ and $\hat{\Lambda}$ are estimates for latent factors and factor loadings from LVHML.

Even though LVHML can be seen as a more general version of the model presented in FLAIR, its current implementation does not allow model fitting if only one time point is used (that is when $T=1$ ), which prevents a comparison when data is generated according to model (S13). Instead, we consider two longitudinal scenarios, both with $T=2$ : in the first one (scenario (a)), for each $i, j$, we observe the outcome at both time points, in the second one (scenario (b)), we observe all the outcomes at the first time point, and only outcomes from the first

# F. 3 Without Covariates scenarios 

We also consider examples without covariates and compare FLAIR to Chen et al. (2019)'s method (JMLE, henceforth) using the R package mirtjml. JMLE considers model (S13) with only the intercept and no additional covariates. Hence, JMLE can be considered as a special case of LVHML with $T=1$ and without covariates. As for LVHML, JMLE assumes the latent factors to be fixed constants and therefore, we make the same adjustment discussed in Section F. 2 to estimate the latent covariance.

We simulate data from the following model

$$
\operatorname{pr}\left(y_{i j}=1 \mid \eta_{i}\right)=h\left(\mu_{0 j}+\lambda_{0 j}^{\top} \eta_{i}\right), \quad \eta_{i} \sim N_{k}\left(0, I_{k}\right), \quad(i=1, \ldots, n)
$$

where loadings and intercepts are generated as follows

$$
\lambda_{0 j l} \sim 0.5 \delta_{0}+0.5 T N\left(0, \sigma^{2},[-5,5]\right), \quad \mu_{0 j} \sim T N\left(0, \sigma^{2},[-5,5]\right), \quad(l=1, \ldots, k ; j=1, \ldots, p)
$$

We let the sample and outcome sizes be $(n, p) \in\{500,1000\} \times\{1000,10000\}$, and set $k=10$ and $\sigma^{2}=0.5$. JMLE imposes a constraint on the Frobenius norm of the parameters and we find the results to be highly sensitive to this choice. To select this hyperparameter, we perform a $80 \% / 20 \%$ train and test split, fit JMLE for each value in $\{1,2, \ldots, 10\}$ on the training set, and pick the value maximizing the area under the curve on the test data. Next, we refit JMLE on the entire data using the chosen hyperparameter. For each run, the optimal value of the hyperparameter was never on the boundary.

Table S6 reports estimation accuracy and running times for both methods. We focus on the normalized Frobenius error for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$, the root mean squared error for $\mu$, and the median and maximum absolute error for the entries of $\mu$. As in the longitudinal experiments, FLAIR obtains better estimation accuracy, which is particularly evident for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and the maximum absolute error for entries of $\mu$. Moreover, FLAIR is remarkably faster, with a gain of a factor of $\approx 5$ when $p=10000$. This gain is for a single model fit that ignores the time taken to repeatedly run JMLE to tune the hyperparameters; FLAIR is run a single time on each data set without the need for such tuning. Table S7 provides further evidence on the validity of credible intervals of FLAIR with only minor under-coverage for $\mu$ when $p=10000$ and precise coverage for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$.

# F. 4 Additional Details for the Numerical Experiments 

In the experiments in the main article, to select the hyperparameters of GMF controlling the $L_{2}$ penalty on $B$ and $\Lambda, \gamma_{B}$ and $\gamma_{\Lambda}$, we estimate the test sample predictive accuracy measured via the area under the curve for each combination of $\left(\gamma_{B}, \gamma_{\Lambda}\right) \in\{0,0.5,1,5,10\} \times\{0,0.5,1,5,10\}$ and refit the model on the entire dataset with the configuration maximizing the area under the curve. The number of latent factors was estimated using via the information criterion discussed in Section 2.5, which always picked the correct value. For FLAIR, we always set $C_{\Lambda}$ and $C_{B}$ to 10 . The code to implement the FLAIR methodology and replicate the experiments is available at https://github.com/maurilorenzo/FLAIR/. All experiments were run on a Laptop with 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1165G7 @ 2.80GHz and 16GB RAM.

## F. 5 Additional Details for the Application to Madagascar Arthropods Data

For GMF, we test each configuration of $\left(\gamma_{B}, \gamma_{\Lambda}\right) \in\{0,0.5,1,5,10,20,50\} \times\{0,0.5,1,5,10,20,50\}$. For FLAIR, we set $C_{\Lambda}$ and $C_{B}$ to 10 . The initialization strategy of FLAIR described in Section D. 1 requires the application of a singular value decomposition to the original data matrix. To avoid using the hold out data in the procedure, we imputed each element of the held out data set. In particular, if the observation $y_{i j}$ was included in the hold out set, we replaced it by the product of the empirical means of the $i$-th row and the $j$-th column of $Y$. We considered other imputation strategies but noticed negligible dependence of the final solution on this choice. Moreover, the FLAIR procedure was trivially modified to include in the calculation of the likelihood for the joint maximum a posteriori computation only observations in the training set.

![table_6](table_6)

Table S5: Comparison of the methods in terms of uncertainty quantification in longitudinal simulation examples. Average frequentist coverage for entries of a random $100 \times 100$ submatrix of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $B$ and length of the corresponding intervals. We report mean and standard deviation over 50 replications. Coverage values have been multiplied by $10^{2}$. All the standard errors for the length of intervals were smaller than 0.01 and omitted. LVIML denote Lee et al. (2024)'s method. For FLAIR, we report results with and without applying the correction factor $\rho$ to the posterior variance.

![table_7](table_7)

Table S6: Comparison of the methods in terms of estimation accuracy in the simulation experiments without covariates. Root normalized squared error for $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $\mu$, median and maximum absolute error for entries of $\mu$, and running time. We report mean and standard deviation over 50 replications. Estimation errors have been multiplied by $10^{2}$. JMLE denote Chen et al. (2019)'s method.

![table_8](table_8)

Table S7: Frequentist coverage for FLAIR with and without applying the correction factor $\rho$ to the posterior variance in the simulation experiments without covariates. Average frequentist coverage for entries of a random $100 \times 100$ submatrix of $\Lambda \Lambda^{\top}$ and $\mu$ for equi-tailed $95 \%$ credible intervals for FLAIR in simulation studies for varying $n$ and $p$ with and without applying the correction factor $\rho$ to the posterior variance. We report mean and standard error over 50 replications. All values have been multiplied by $10^{2}$.

abstract:
This article focuses on inference in logistic regression for high-dimensional
binary outcomes. A popular approach induces dependence across the outcomes by
including latent factors in the linear predictor. Bayesian approaches are
useful for characterizing uncertainty in inferring the regression coefficients,
factors and loadings, while also incorporating hierarchical and shrinkage
structure. However, Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms for posterior
computation face challenges in scaling to high-dimensional outcomes. Motivated
by applications in ecology, we exploit a blessing of dimensionality to motivate
pre-estimation of the latent factors. Conditionally on the factors, the
outcomes are modeled via independent logistic regressions. We implement
Gaussian approximations in parallel in inferring the posterior on the
regression coefficients and loadings, including a simple adjustment to obtain
credible intervals with valid frequentist coverage. We show posterior
concentration properties and excellent empirical performance in simulations.
The methods are applied to insect biodiversity data in Madagascar.
